questions.question: For the nursing council to find a registered nurse guilt of malpractice following an assault on a client, it would have to prove that the nurse
options: Intended to cause bodily harm to the client
Did not establish a therapeutic relationship with the client
Committed a felony against the client
questions.explanation: Assault requires intent to cause apprehension of harm.

questions.question: Emergency interventions for a victim with upper torso injuries or face, head, or neck trauma include
options: Immobilization of the cervical spine Page 36 of 203
Ensuring venous access with at least two large bore IV lines
questions.explanation: With head/neck/face injuries, assume cervical spine injury—immobilise.

questions.question: An employee spilled industrial acids on his arms and legs at work. The appropriate action by the occupational nurse at the facility is to
options: Apply cool compresses to the area of exposure
Apply an alkaline solution to the affected area
Cover the affected area with dry, sterile dressings
Flush the substance with large amounts of tap water
questions.explanation: Immediately flush acids with copious water to dilute/remove.

questions.question: According to the privacy act 1993, when collecting health information from a client the nurse must
options: Ensure the client is aware that health information is being collected
Tell the client why health information is being collected
Inform the client about their rights of access and correction
questions.explanation: Privacy Act: inform that you are collecting data, why, and rights—do all.

questions.question: An example of the use of primary prevention for family violence is
options: Working to eliminate the glamorisation of violence on television
Counselling a woman living in an abusive relationship about available shelter programs
Calling child protective services regarding a school age child who has reported sexual attacks by her stepfather
Carefully examining the skin of an elder who has just returned to an extended care facility following a weekend with his children
questions.explanation: Primary prevention: address media glamorisation and societal norms.

questions.question: With a patient who is homosexual, the nurses most appropriate initial action during the preinteraction phase of the relationship should be to
options: Assist the patient in changing sexual values
Examine own feelings and anxieties with regard to the patient
Review the literature pertaining to the human sexual response
Attempt to identify the underlying reasons for the patients values
questions.explanation: Preinteraction: examine one’s own attitudes and anxieties.

questions.question: The nurse judges that the mother understands the term cerebral palsy when she describes it as a term applied to impaired movement resulting from which of the following
options: Injury to the cerebrum caused by viral infection
Malformed blood vessels in the ventricles caused by inheritance
Non progressive brain damage caused by injury
Inflammatory brain disease caused by metabolic imbalances
questions.explanation: Cerebral palsy is non‑progressive brain damage causing motor impairment.

questions.question: The first symptom of gonorrhoea is usually
options: A sore or ulcer on the genitals
Purulent vaginal discharge in the female Page 37 of 203
questions.explanation: Earliest sign is urethral discharge in males.

questions.question: The first symptom of syphilis is
options: A generalised rash all over the body
A sore or ulcer on the genitals
questions.explanation: Primary syphilis presents with a painless genital chancre/ulcer.

questions.question: When obtaining a nursing history from parents who are suspected of abusing their child, which of the following characteristics about the parents would the nurse typically find
options: Self blame for the injury to the child
Ability to relate child‟s developmental achievements
Evidence of little concern over the extent of the injury
questions.explanation: Abusive parents often show little concern over the child’s injuries.

questions.question: A colleague comments: what is the relevance of the treaty of Waitangi to Maori health
options: Maori people view the treaty of Waitangi as a health document
Nursing practice in new Zealand is congruent with the treaty of Waitangi
The right to health is guaranteed to Maori under article two of the treaty of Waitangi
The right to Maori involvement in health is guaranteed
questions.explanation: The Treaty guarantees Māori involvement/participation in health.

questions.question: The long term consequences of Chlamydia is most likely to be
questions.explanation: Untreated chlamydia can lead to infertility (tubal scarring).

questions.question: When describing the effects of insulin on the body to a patient newly diagnosed with diabetes mellitus, the best explanation by the nurse is
options: Insulin promotes the breakdown of fatty tissue into triglycerides, which can be used for energy
When proteins are taken into the body, insulin promotes their breakdown and conversion to fats
Insulin stimulates the conversion of stored sugars into blood glucose and the conversion of proteins into glucose
When carbohydrates, fats, and proteins are eaten, insulin promotes cellular transport and storage of all these nutrients
questions.explanation: Insulin promotes cellular uptake and storage of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

questions.question: A serious complication of acute malaria is
options: Fluid and electrolyte imbalance Page 38 of 203
questions.explanation: Severe malaria risks F&E imbalance and shock; monitor and replace aggressively.

questions.question: A registered nurse stops to assist at the scene of an accident but the injured man dies before the ambulance arrives. The nurse should understand that she
options: Should leave the scene before the ambulance arrives
Will be covered by her actions by the good Samaritan laws
Has a legal duty of care to perform at a competent level as a registered nurse
Should pronounce the person dead at the scene STATE EXAMS 5
questions.explanation: Once assisting, you owe a competent duty of care as an RN.

questions.question: John is admitted with neutropenia, what does the nurse assess in determining his risk for infection
options: Length of time neutropenia has existed
questions.explanation: Infection risk rises with the duration of neutropenia.

questions.question: What nursing action would be important in preventing cross contamination
options: Stand two feet from the patient
Speak minimally when in the room
questions.explanation: Changing gloves immediately prevents cross contamination.

questions.question: What would you teach john and his family to avoid
options: Using a high efficiency particulate air filter mask
Performing perineal care after every bowel movement
Performing oral care after every meal
questions.explanation: Avoid rectal procedures (suppositories/enemas) in neutropenia.

questions.question: 24 hours after john has a bone marrow aspiration, the nurse evaluates which of the following as an appropriate client outcome
options: There is redness and swelling at the aspiration site
The client requests morphine sulphate 2mg IM every 2 hours
There is no bleeding at aspiration site
questions.explanation: Desired: no bleeding at aspiration site after 24h.

questions.question: During the induction stage for treatment of leukaemia, the nurse should remove which items that the family has brought into the room
questions.explanation: Remove scented/herbal items—potential contaminants/allergens.

questions.question: The goal of nursing care for a client with acute myeloid leukaemia is to prevent
questions.explanation: AML complications include bleeding from thrombocytopenia—prevent haemorrhage.

questions.question: The nurse is evaluating the clients learning about combination chemotherapy. Which of the following statements about reasons for using combination chemotherapy indicates the need for further explanation
options: Combination chemotherapy is used to interrupt cell growth cycle at different points
Combination chemo is used to destroy cancer cells and treat side effects simultaneously
Combination chemo is used to decrease resistance
Combination chemo is used to minimise the toxicity from using high doses of single agent
questions.explanation: Combo chemo is not used to treat side effects; that statement is incorrect.

questions.question: In providing care to the client with leukaemia who has developed thrombocytopenia, the nurse assessed the most common sites for bleeding. Which of the following is not a common site
questions.explanation: Biliary system bleeding is uncommon compared to GI, pulmonary, CNS.

questions.question: The nurses best explanation for why the severely neutropenic client is place in reverse isolation is that reverse isolation helps prevent the spread of organisms
options: To the client from sources outside the clients environment
From the client to health care personnel, visitors and other clients
By using special techniques to dispose of contaminated material
By using special techniques to hand the clients linens and personal items
questions.explanation: Reverse isolation protects the neutropenic client from external pathogens.

questions.question: A client has received 25ml of packed red blood cells when she began to experience low back pain and mild itching. After stopping the transfusion the nurse should
options: Collect blood and urine samples to be sent to the laboratory
Administer prescribed diuretics, oxygen and morphine
questions.explanation: For mild allergic reaction, stop transfusion and give antihistamine/antipyretic as ordered.

questions.question: The nurse in the preoperative period is preparing a female client for surgery and notices that the client looks sad. The client says, „I‟m scared of having cancer. It‟s so horrible and I brought it on myself. I should have quit smoking years ago‟. What would be the nurses best response to the client
options: It‟s okay to be scared. What is it about cancer that you‟re afraid of
It‟s normal to be scared. I would be too. Well help you through it
Don‟t be hard on yourself. You don‟t know if your smoking caused the cancer
Do you feel guilty because you smoked
questions.explanation: Empathic, open-ended acknowledgment invites expression of fears.

questions.question: Following mastectomy the client is now due to have radiation therapy. She should be taught to care for the skin at the therapy site by
options: Exposing the area to dry heat
Applying an ointment to the area
Using talcum powder on the area Page 40 of 203
questions.explanation: Use only water/gentle washing; avoid heat, ointments, powders on irradiated skin.

questions.question: A 42 year old woman is interested in making dietary changes to reduce her risk of colon cancer. What dietary selections would the nurse suggest
options: Croissant, peanut butter, sandwiches, whole milk
Bran muffin, skim milk, sir fried broccoli
Bagel with cream cheese, cauliflower salad
questions.explanation: High‑fibre, low‑fat foods help reduce colon cancer risk.

questions.question: The nurse is teaching a 19 year old client and the client‟s family about what to expect with high dose chemotherapy and the effects of neutropenia. What should the nurse teach as the most reliable early indicator of infection in a neutropenic client
questions.explanation: Fever is the most reliable early sign of infection in neutropenia.

questions.question: The client is being discharged with oral chemotherapy, in teaching the client and family how to manage nausea and vomiting at home, which of the following should be discussed
options: Eating frequent, small meals throughout the day
Eating three normal meals a day
Eating only cold food but no salads
Limiting the amount of fluid intake
questions.explanation: Frequent small meals help reduce nausea/vomiting at home.

questions.question: In setting up a syringe driver to administer analgesia which of the following factors would be most important for the nurse to consider when determining the angle at which to insert the needle
questions.explanation: Angle depends on subcutaneous tissue depth (45° vs 90°).

questions.question: A client is diagnosed with metastatic bone cancer. Which of the following abnormal laboratory values would the nurse expect to see
questions.explanation: Bone metastases elevate alkaline phosphatase from osteoblastic activity.

questions.question: Mrs Johnson has had a recurrence of breast cancer and has been managed at home with support from the palliative care nurse specialist. This morning when visiting her, the nurse noted she was experiencing severe low back pain especially when lying down. Which of the following assessments would be the priority
questions.explanation: Spinal/brain metastasis risk—neurological assessment is priority.

questions.question: The nurse would teach the client that a normal local tissue response to radiation is
options: Atrophy of the skin Page 41 of 203
Sloughing of two layers of skin
questions.explanation: Erythema is a common local response to radiation.

questions.question: The husband of a client with cervical cancer says to the nurse, „the doctor told my wife that her cancer is curable. Is he just trying to make us feel better.‟ Which would be the nurses most accurate response
options: When cervical cancer is detected early and treated aggressively, the cure rate is almost 100%
The 5 year survival rate is about 75%, which makes the odds pretty good
Saying a cancer is curable means that 50% of all women with cancer survive at least 5 years
Cancers of the female reproductive tract tend to be slow growing and respond well to treatment
questions.explanation: By definition, 'curable' cancers have ~50% 5‑year survival in population terms.

questions.question: A priority nursing diagnosis for a client with cervical cancer who has an internal radium implant would be
options: Anxiety related to self care deficit from imposed immobility during radiation
Impaired health maintenance related to surgery
Disturbed sleep pattern related to interruptions by health care personnel
questions.explanation: Internal radiation requires immobilisation; anxiety/self‑care deficit is common.

questions.question: The nurse should carefully observe a client with internal radium implants for typical side effects associated with radiation therapy to the cervix. These effects include
options: High fever in the afternoon or evening
Nausea and a foul vaginal discharge
questions.explanation: Cervical radiation can cause cystitis/diarrhoea—watch for bowel/bladder changes and fever.

questions.question: A terminally ill client‟s husband tells the nurse, „I wish we had taken that trip to Europe last year. We just kept putting it off, and now I‟m furious that we didn‟t go.‟ The nurse interprets that husbands statement as indicating which of the following stages of adapt ion to dying
questions.explanation: Shock goals: restore tissue perfusion.

questions.question: A client is newly diagnosed with cancer and is beginning a treatment plan. Which of the following nursing interventions will be most effective in helping the client cope
options: Assume decision making for the client
Encourage strict compliance with all treatment regimens
Inform the client of all possible adverse treatment effects
questions.explanation: Early shock often shows restlessness/anxiety from hypoxia.

questions.question: Mr Green has been admitted terminally ill and in need of pain management. He has now been commenced on oral morphine. What would you also ensure the doctor prescribe at this time
questions.explanation: Compensatory shock: tachycardia to maintain CO.

questions.question: A client sustained an open fracture of the femur from an automobile accident. For which of the following types of shock should the client be assessed
questions.explanation: Anaphylactic shock: airway patency is first priority.

questions.question: What is the primary goal for the care of a client who is in shock
questions.explanation: Vasoactive drugs are titrated to maintain vascular tone/pressure in shock.

questions.question: Which of the following findings would the nurse most likely note in the client who is in the compensatory stage of shock
questions.explanation: Oliguria is typical in compensatory stage due to renal vasoconstriction.

questions.question: Two days after the fracture of his femur, a client suddenly complains of chest pain and dyspnoea. The nurse also notes some confusion and an elevated temperature. Based on these assessment findings, the nurse suspects which of the following complications
questions.explanation: Sudden dyspnoea, petechiae, fever post long‑bone fracture = fat embolism.

questions.question: When the nurse asked her client and partner what type of birth control they were planning to use, they stated that since she is breast feeding, they don‟t need to have to worry about birth control. The nurse should tell them that
options: They can decide on a method when Cindy stops breast feeding
No birth control is necessary until after the first menstrual period
Ovulation can occur when a woman is breast feeding
Since Cindy has become pregnant once, it will be much easier for her to become pregnant now
questions.explanation: Ovulation can occur during breastfeeding; contraception still needed.

questions.question: During the post partum period many women experience mood swings which are referred to as
options: Attachment to the infant Page 43 of 203
questions.explanation: Postpartum blues = transient mood lability in first days.

questions.question: According to Erikson, an infant is in the psychosocial stage that is characterised by the conflict of
questions.explanation: Erikson infant: trust vs mistrust.

questions.question: Mrs Cindy Jackson, para 1, gravid 1, had a vaginal delivery of a full term baby yesterday. Because of the soreness of her perineum, Cindy states that she is afraid to have a bowel movement. The nurse should encourage Cindy to
options: Ambulate frequently, eat fresh fruits and vegetables, and drink 6 – 8 glasses water per day
Ask her doctor to prescribe a laxative to stimulate defecation
Drink 2 glasses of warm water after every meal, then try to defecate
Do kegel exercises twice a day, eat a low roughage diet, and drink ten glasses of water per day
questions.explanation: Sickle cell vaso‑occlusion causes severe pain—control pain is priority.

questions.question: Mrs Frederick is scheduled for exploratory and palliative surgery the next day. Results of blood tests show that she has a microcytic anaemia Likely causes of microcytic anaemia is 1. A diet low in iron 2. A diet low in vitamin C 3. Chronic blood loss 4. Acute blood loss 5. Haemolytic streptococcal infection
questions.explanation: CBC abnormal in haematologic disease—anaemia common in leukaemia.

questions.question: Mrs Frederick is to have a blood transfusion of two units of packed cells, prior to surgery. She is charted 350 mls over three hours through a blood giving set with a drip factor of 15 How many drops per minute will you run the blood at
questions.explanation: Splenomegaly is typical in acute leukaemia.

questions.question: If Mrs. Frederick were to receive blood with which she is incompatible, the signs and symptoms we would see, would include 1. Restlessness and anxiety 2. Generalised tingling sensations 3. Nausea and vomiting 4. Elevated temperature 5. Decreased blood pressure
questions.explanation: Typhoid localises in Peyer’s patches of the ileum.

questions.question: If a client who suffers from cancer of the colon, the most common site of metastases is the
questions.explanation: The spleen is vulnerable to enlargement/rupture in infections.

questions.question: Which of the following post operative complications may be avoided by pre operative teaching
questions.explanation: Pre‑op teaching (deep breathing/mobility) prevents hypostatic pneumonia.

questions.question: Haemorrhage during the first 12 hours post operatively is termed
questions.explanation: Reactionary haemorrhage occurs within first 12h post‑op.

questions.question: Mary aged 45 years is admitted to the ward for planned surgery. Mary smokes 20 cigarettes a day and drinks three glasses of wine every evening The significance of this information for you is so that you
options: May teach deep breathing and coughing and relaxation techniques in preparation for surgery
Be aware of a potentially addictive personality when planning her pain relief post operatively
Can assist her to break her smoking and drinking habits when in hospital
May plan to include cigarettes and alcohol in her post operative regime
questions.explanation: Teach DB&C and relaxation to reduce pulmonary complications.

questions.question: Two days later, Mary has a cholecystectomy performed, successfully. On her return to the ward, Mary has an upper abdominal wound with a redivac, a T tube, A naso gastric tube and an intravenous infusion in situ When carrying out Marys post operative exercise regime, which aspect should receive the highest priority
options: Ensuring Mary has privacy and freedom from interruption
That Mary knows how to breathe and cough and why it is important
That she knows how to support her wound and that her pain is under control
That there be no interruption by Marys family and friends when they visit
questions.explanation: Support wound and manage pain to facilitate deep breathing/coughing.

questions.question: Mr Evere, a 69 year old retired musician was admitted to the intensive care unit with a diagnosis of Adams stokes syndrome The nurse notes mr everes pulse pressure is decreasing. Pulse pressure is the
options: Difference between the apical and radial rates
Force exerted against an arterial wall
Degree of ventricular contraction in relation to output Page 45 of 203
Difference between systolic and diastolic readings
questions.explanation: Pulse pressure = systolic − diastolic pressure.

questions.question: The physician suspects cardiogenic shock. Shock is
options: Always caused by decreased blood volume
A fleeting reaction to tissue injury
questions.explanation: COPD ABG: chronic ↑PaCO₂, ↓PaO₂—hypoxaemia with hypercapnia.

questions.question: The physical law explaining the greatly increased venous return accompanying mild vasoconstriction underlies the use of
questions.explanation: Avoid high‑flow oxygen in CO₂ retainers—use minimal to maintain sats.

questions.question: Culturally safe nursing care can best be achieved when the nurse has
options: An in depth knowledge of the treaty of Waitangi
An awareness of Maori perspectives of health
An awareness and acceptance of your own limits in meeting someone else‟s health and cultural needs
questions.explanation: Most asthma in children is extrinsic (atopic) with eosinophilia and triggers.

questions.question: Imagine a new virus infecting a human population for the first time. Which of the following is most likely to lead to a rapid increase in cases worldwide
questions.explanation: Acidosis stimulates breathing; alkalosis depresses—acidosis increases ventilation.

questions.question: The school nurse is caring for a child with haemophilia who is actively bleeding from the leg. Which of the following would the nurse apply
options: Direct pressure, checking every few minutes to see if the bleeding has stopped
Ice to the injured leg area several times a day
Direct pressure to the injured area continuously for 10 minutes
Ice bag with elevation of the leg twice a day
questions.explanation: Firm pressure x10 minutes for haemophilia‑related bleeding.

questions.question: Home health nurses visit a blind diabetic patient who lives along to monitor the patient‟s glucose level and administer the patient‟s daily insulin. Evaluation of outcome management for this patient would include
options: An absence of complications of diabetes
A reduction in hospitalizations for glycemic control
The ability of the patient to learn to use adaptive syringes
The patients evaluation of the services provided by the nurses
questions.explanation: Outcome: fewer admissions for glycaemic control reflects effective self‑management.

questions.question: The nurse consults with the physician to arrange a referral for hospice care for a patient with end stage liver disease based on the knowledge that hospice care is indicated when
options: Family members can no longer care for dying patients at home
Patients and families are having difficulty coping with grief reactions Page 46 of 203
Preparation for death with palliative care and comfort are the goals of care
Patients have unmanageable pain and suffering as a result of their condition
questions.explanation: Hospice when goals are comfort/palliation and preparation for death.

questions.question: To better understand fluid balance the nurse needs to recognise that
options: Glomerular filtration occurs in the glomerular which are small arteries in the kidneys
The volume of urine secreted is regulated mainly by mechanisms that control the glomerular filtration rate
An increase in the hydrostatic pressure in bowman‟s capsule tends to increase the glomerular filtration rate
A decrease in blood protein concentration tends to increase the glomerular filtration rate
questions.explanation: GFR regulation controls urine volume; ↑Bowman’s pressure reduces GFR; ↓plasma protein increases GFR.

questions.question: The client with unresolved oedema is most likely to develop
questions.explanation: Persistent oedema compromises perfusion → tissue ischaemia.

questions.question: Women are more susceptible to urinary tract infection because of
questions.explanation: Short urethra predisposes women to UTIs.

questions.question: The most important electrolyte of intracellular fluid is
questions.explanation: Potassium is the principal intracellular cation.

questions.question: In encouraging hospitalised clients to void the most basic methods for the nurse to employ is
options: Having the client listen to running water
Placing the clients hand in warm water
questions.explanation: Iron‑deficiency anaemia: give iron, not transfuse unless severe.

questions.question: Since Mr. Saul has right hemiplegia the nurse contributes to his rehabilitation by
options: Making a referral to the physio therapist
Not moving the affected arm and leg unless necessary
Positioning Mr. Saul to prevent deformity and decubiti
questions.explanation: RA = autoimmune inflammation; treat with immunosuppressants/NSAIDs/rest/exercise.

questions.question: Mr Saul's emotions responses to his illness would probably be determined by
options: His ability to understand his illness Page 47 of 203
questions.explanation: Acute gout: avoid alcohol—triggers attacks.

questions.question: Mrs Olin, a retired school teacher with rheumatoid arthritis, is admitted to hospital with severe pain and swelling of the joints in both hands Mrs Olin‟s condition would indicate that a primary consideration of her care is
questions.explanation: Post‑op pain control is key for deep breathing and mobility.

questions.question: While taking a nursing history from Mrs. Olin, the nurse promotes communication by
options: Asking questions that can be answered by a simple „yes‟ or „no‟
Telling Mrs. Olin there‟s no cause for alarm
questions.explanation: Use open‑ended questions to encourage communication.

questions.question: Mr and Mrs. B were emotionally upset when their baby girl, sue, was born with a cleft palate and double cleft lip The nurse, in order to give the most support to the parents, should
options: Discourage them from talking about the baby
Encourage them to express their worries and fears
Tell them not to worry because the defect can be repaired
Show them post operative photographs of babies who had similar defects
questions.explanation: Encourage expression of feelings/worries to support grieving parents.

questions.question: The most critical factor in the immediate care of sue, after repair of the lip is
options: Administration of drugs to reduce secretions
questions.explanation: Airway is always first after cleft lip repair.

questions.question: Additional nursing care for sue after the original lip repair would include
options: Placing the baby in a semi sitting position
Spoon feeding for the first two days after surgery
Keeping the baby nil per mouth
questions.explanation: Avoid crying to protect suture line; gentle positioning as ordered.

questions.question: Seven year old Johnny has been admitted for a tonsillectomy. The nurse suspects haemorrhage post operatively when Johnny
questions.explanation: Pallor, frequent swallowing indicate bleeding after tonsillectomy.

questions.question: Pitting oedema in the lower extremities occurs with this problem because of the
options: Increase in tissue colloid osmotic pressure
Increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure at the arterial end of the capillary bed
Decrease in the plasma colloid osmotic pressure
Increase in the plasma hydrostatic pressure at the venous end of the capillary beds
questions.explanation: Signs suggest acute asthma attack; assist with inhaler and seek review.

questions.question: The nurse can best assess the degree of oedema in an extremity by
options: Measuring the affected area Page 48 of 203
questions.explanation: Slow pursed‑lip breathing helps COPD—avoid bag/CO₂ issues.

questions.question: Mrs Smith is hospitalised with coronary heart disease. She is receiving IV fluids, her vital signs are checked 4 hourly. She is on bed rest. She was also prescribed digoxin. She does not seem to be acutely sick but her prognosis is guarded. Mrs Smith asks what the coronary arteries have to do with her angina. In determining the answer, the nurse should take into consideration that coronary arteries
options: Carry reduced oxygen content blood to the lungs
Carry blood from aorta to the myocardium
Carry high oxygen blood from the lungs towards the heart
questions.explanation: Activity intolerance: dyspnoea at rest indicates severe impairment—rest required.

questions.question: After activity Mrs. Smith states she has angina pain. The nurse should realise that angina pectoris is a sign of
questions.explanation: Stop med and check level/assess—then contact provider if toxic signs.

questions.question: During therapy with salbutamol (venolin) Mr. Peters complains of palpitation, chest pain, and a throbbing headache. In view of these symptoms which of the following statements represent the most appropriate nursing action
options: Reassure Mr. peters that these effects are temporary and will subside as he becomes accustomed to the drug
Withhold the drug until additional orders are obtained from the physician
Tell him not to worry, he is experiencing expected side effects of medicine
Ask him to relax, then instruct him to breath slowly for several minutes
questions.explanation: Coach slow breathing for hyperventilation‑type dyspnoea.

questions.question: Mr Peters pulmonary function studies are abnormal. The nurse should realise that one of the most common complication of chronic asthma is A) Athelectasis B) Emphysema C) Pneumothorax D) Pulmonary fibrosis 3. Emphysema causes a failure in oxygen supply because of
questions.explanation: Emphysema reduces alveolar surface area for gas exchange.

questions.question: When the alveoli loose normal elasticity, the nurse teaches Mr. peters exercises that lead to effective use of the diaphragm because
options: Mr peters has an increase in the vital capacity of the lungs
The residual capacity of the lungs has been increased
Inspiration has been markedly prolonged and difficult
Abdominal breathing is an effective compensatory mechanism that is spontaneously initiated Page 49 of 203
questions.explanation: Diaphragmatic breathing compensates when elastic recoil is lost.

questions.question: Mr hurt has developed acute renal failure and uraemia. Metabolic acidosis develops in renal failure as a result of
options: depression of respiratory rate by metabolic wastes causing carbon dioxide retention
inability of renal tubules to secrete hydrogen ions and conserve bicarbonate
inability of renal tubules to reabsorb water to achieve dilution of acid contents of the blood
impaired glomerular filtration causing retention of sodium and metabolic waste products
questions.explanation: ARF: can’t secrete H+ or reabsorb HCO₃⁻ → metabolic acidosis.

questions.question: of the following, which is most important in maintaining the fluid and electrolyte balance of the body
questions.explanation: ADH is key moment‑to‑moment regulator of water balance.

questions.question: to prevent laryngeal spasms and respiratory arrest in a patient who is at risk for hypocalcaemia, an early sign of hypocalcaemia the nurse should assess for is
options: numbness and tingling around the lips or in the fingers
questions.explanation: Hypocalcaemia early sign = tetany (e.g., Chvostek/Trousseau).

questions.question: A 36 year old woman has been admitted to the hospital for knee surgery. Information obtained by the nurse during the preoperative assessment that should be reported to the surgeon before surgery is performed includes the patients
options: lack of knowledge about postoperative pain control
knowledge of the possibility of an early, unplanned pregnancy
history of a postoperative infection following a prior cholecystectomy
concern that she will be physically limited in caring for her children for a period postoperatively
questions.explanation: High output (≥35 mL/h) indicates adequate perfusion post‑burns; low BP is worrying.

questions.question: in is especially important for the nurse to determine the patients current use of medications during the preoperative assessment because
options: these medications may alter the patients perceptions about surgery
anaesthetics alter renal and hepatic function, causing toxicity by other drugs
other medications may cause interactions with anaesthetics, altering the potency and effect of the drugs
routine medications are usually withheld the day of surgery, requiring dosage and schedule adjustments
questions.explanation: Acute appendicitis: RLQ pain, rebound tenderness, fever.

questions.question: A client with type 1 diabetes mellitus is scheduled to have surgery. The client has been nil per mouth since midnight in preparation for the surgery. In the morning before sending the client to the operating room, the nurse notices that the client‟s daily insulin has not been ordered. Which of the following interventions would be most appropriate for the nurse at this time
options: obtain the clients blood glucose values and evaluate the clients need for insulin
contact the physician for further orders regarding insulin administration
give the clients usual morning dose of insulin Page 50 of 203
notify the recovery room staff to obtain an order for insulin after the surgery
questions.explanation: Check current glucose and tailor insulin per orders—do not automatically give usual dose pre‑op.

questions.question: the nurse monitors a patient receiving high doses of broad spectrum antibiotics for treatment of endocarditis for the development of
questions.explanation: Post‑op priorities include early ambulation to prevent complications.

questions.question: The nurse is evaluating the effectiveness of fluid resuscitation during the emergent period of burn management. Which of the following indicates that adequate fluid replacement has been achieved in the client
options: fluid intake is less than urinary output
questions.explanation: Adequate resuscitation is reflected by urine output ≥ 35 mL/hr in adults.

questions.question: Cimetidine (tagamet) is prescribed for a patient with major burns. In teaching the patient about the drug, the nurse explains that it is used to prevent the development of
questions.explanation: Curling’s ulcers are stress ulcers after burns; H2 blockers like cimetidine reduce gastric acid to prevent them.

questions.question: A client who has had a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) 1 day earlier has a three way foley catheter inserted for continuous bladder irrigation. Which of the following statements best explains why continuous irrigation is used after a TURP
options: to control bleeding in the bladder
to instil antibiotics into the bladder
to keep the catheter free from clot obstruction
questions.explanation: Continuous bladder irrigation keeps the catheter lumen free of clots after TURP.

questions.question: A patient in severe respiratory distress is admitted to the medical unit at the hospital. During the admission assessment of the patient, the nurse should
options: perform a comprehensive health history with the patient to determine the extent of prior respiratory problems
complete a full physical examination to determine the effect of the respiratory distress on other body functions
delay any physical assessment of the patient and ask family members about the patients history of respiratory problems
perform a physical assessment of the respiratory system and ask specific questions related to this episode of respiratory distress
questions.explanation: Focus on respiratory assessment and relevant history to this episode; full history later.

questions.question: spinal anaesthesia effects all of the following systems except
questions.explanation: Spinal anaesthesia blocks sympathetic, sensory, and motor; parasympathetic least affected.

questions.question: Following assessment of a patient with pneumonia, the nurse identifies a nursing diagnosis of ineffective airway clearance. The nurse bases this nursing diagnosis on the finding of
options: Crackles in the right and left lower lobes
questions.explanation: SpO₂ 85% indicates impaired gas exchange and cyanosis risk.

questions.question: To protect susceptible patients in the hospital from aspiration pneumonia, the nurse
options: Turns and repositions immobile patients every 2 hours
Positions patients with altered consciousness in lateral positions
Monitors for respiratory symptoms in those patients who are immunosuppressed
Plans room assignments to prevent patients with infections from being placed with surgical or chronically ill patients
questions.explanation: Early CHF pulmonary oedema: dyspnoea on exertion.

questions.question: A patient experiences a flail chest as a result of an automobile accident. Which finding during a respiratory assessment would the nurse expect
questions.explanation: Pulse 120 suggests tachycardia indicating possible CHF decompensation.

questions.question: A client is admitted to the emergency room with crushing chest injuries sustained in a car accident. Which of the following signs would indicate a possible pneumothorax
options: Diminished or absent breath sounds on the affected side
A decreased sensation on the affected side
questions.explanation: Leg elevation and isometric ankle pumps prevent DVT/PE.

questions.question: Joan Murray, aged 40 years, discovers a lump in the upper and outer quadrant of her left breast when she is showering one morning. One week later, after being seen by a surgeon, she is admitted to the ward for a biopsy of the lump and possible left radical mastectomy. In establishing a relationship with Joan, what is the most important factor for the nurse to consider. That
options: The diagnosis has not yet been established and the breast lump is not necessarily malignant
Joan will have many questions about the possible effects of a mastectomy on her sexual identity
At this time of uncertainty, Joan will need a lot of time to be alone to consider her choices
Joan will be full of fear about the mass and its possible effects on her being
questions.explanation: Arterial flow is augmented by calf muscle (muscular) pump.

questions.question: Part of Joan's pre operative preparation is practising arm and shoulder exercises. The reason for these exercises are
options: She can be assured of maximum function of her arm and shoulder if these exercises are carried out properly
That they help reduce the pain and the swelling in the area, after surgery
To assist peripheral venous return and thus reduce the potential for pulmonary embolus
By being involved in activities related to her care, Joan is less likely to worry Page 52 of 203
questions.explanation: Early mobilisation reduces venous stasis and oedema.

questions.question: The reason we position Joan‟s affected arm with her elbow at the level of the right atrium and her hand higher than her elbow is to
options: Ensure that the area is supported
questions.explanation: Elevate hand above elbow and elbow at RA level to minimise oedema.

questions.question: The primary ossification center of long bone is located in which of the following structures
questions.explanation: Primary ossification centre is in the diaphysis.

questions.question: The body tissue affected by rheumatoid arthritis is
questions.explanation: RA affects connective tissue (synovium).

questions.question: The pattern of rheumatoid arthritis is best describe by its
options: Little relief from aches and pains
questions.explanation: RA course shows remissions and exacerbations.

questions.question: Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by
questions.explanation: RA hallmark is synovitis causing joint inflammation.

questions.question: Synovial joints are characterized by
questions.explanation: Inactive exercise maintains function without stressing inflamed joints.

questions.question: the major support that the muscular system gets from the cardiovascular system
options: a direct response by controlling the heart rate and the respiratory rate
constriction of blood vessels and decrease in heart rate for thermoregulatory control
nutrient and oxygen delivery and carbon dioxide removal
decreased volume of blood and rate of flow for maximal muscle contraction
questions.explanation: Bronchioles are smallest airways; bronchi larger; trachea largest.

questions.question: as the nurse assesses jack for increased intracranial pressure, she would be concerned if she observed
options: increased pulse and respiration rates Page 53 of 203
blurred vision and halos around lights
questions.explanation: RBCs live ~120 days.

questions.question: A person has just been involved in an accident that affected the medulla oblongata. The body process most directly affected by this would be
questions.explanation: Coronary circulation supplies the heart muscle.

questions.question: if you are dealing with a person whose phrenic nerve has been damaged, what would you expect to observe
options: less mucous secreted by the goblet cells
decreased elasticity of the lung tissue
questions.explanation: Restrictive lung disease shows decreased total lung capacity.

questions.question: the spinal cord extends through the vertebral canal from the foramen magnum to the
questions.explanation: Spinal cord ends at L2 in adults.

questions.question: Synaptic conduction of a nerve impulse can be affected by
questions.explanation: Diseases, drugs, and pH all affect synaptic conduction.

questions.question: Lack of muscle coordination is called
questions.explanation: Ataxia = lack of coordination.

questions.question: Inability of chew might result from damage to which cranial nerve
questions.explanation: Trigeminal (V) innervates muscles of mastication.

questions.question: In most people, the left cerebral hemisphere is more important for which of the following
questions.explanation: Left hemisphere is dominant for language in most people.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning the limbic system
options: It is comprised of parts of the cerebrum and diencephalon
It assumes a primary function in emotions
Both a and b Page 54 of 203
questions.explanation: Four valves: 2 atrioventricular and 2 semilunar.

questions.question: Coordination of muscular activity is a function of the
questions.explanation: A sprain involves ligament injury.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct
options: Appetite control is a function of the thalamus
The midbrain is a conduction pathway and reflex center
The cerebellum has sensory centres for thirst and speech
Respiratory centres are located in the basal ganglia
questions.explanation: Axis = C2, second cervical vertebra.

questions.question: The structure that connects the cerebral hemispheres and facilitates the sharing of cerebral information is the
questions.explanation: Rickets results from vitamin D deficiency causing bone weakness.

questions.question: The portion of bone laid down first in bone formation is the
questions.explanation: Marrow fills medullary cavity, not trabeculae in long bones.

questions.question: The area of the greatest degree of flexibility along with the vertebral column is found from
questions.explanation: Cervical region C3–C7 has greatest flexibility.

questions.question: The only ankle bone that articulates with the tibia and the fibula is the
questions.explanation: Talus articulates with tibia and fibula.

questions.question: Severe fractures of the femoral neck have the highest complication rate of any fracture because
options: Primary limits are imposed by the surrounding muscles
Of the restrictions imposed by ligaments and capsular fibers
Of the thickness and length of the bone
The blood supply to the region is relatively delicate
questions.explanation: Femoral neck fractures risk avascular necrosis due to tenuous blood supply.

questions.question: The purpose of myoglobin in skeletal muscle cells is
options: Store oxygen for use during vigorous exercise Page 55 of 203
questions.explanation: Myoglobin stores O₂ in muscle cells for vigorous exercise.

questions.question: With a milk product free diet, which of the following supplements would you need
questions.explanation: Milk-free diet needs calcium (and often vitamin D); manganese less typical—best option calcium + manganese.

questions.question: Protein should be eaten as it
options: Ensures an adequate supply of energy
Assists the body to produce new tissues
questions.explanation: Common cold is viral; antibiotics not indicated.

questions.question: Risk factors of CVA that cannot be altered are
options: Sex, race, and raised blood cholesterol levels
High BP, previous TIA and increased blood cholesterol levels
questions.explanation: Vision change in one eye more likely stroke—treat as emergency.

questions.question: A person who has experienced a right CVA may present with
questions.explanation: Three risk factors listed—select option with three: hypertension, smoking, diabetes.

questions.question: Where and what is the circle of Willis
options: A capillary meshwork found in bowman‟s capsule of the nephron
A vascular network at the base of the brain
A roundabout at the top of bank st
The capsule membrane of a malignant growth
questions.explanation: Heart transplant contraindicated with severe systemic disease (e.g., widespread cancer).

questions.question: List the 3 main causes of stroke
questions.explanation: Cerebral embolus/coagulopathy cause strokes; match best combination.

questions.question: Angina symptoms include
options: Radiating pain, decreased BP and increased pulse
Shortness of breath, loss of consciousness and these effects may last indefinitely
Ringing in the ears, anxiety and cramping in the extremities
Shortness of breath, sweating, nausea and tiredness
questions.explanation: Typical angina symptoms include SOB, sweating, nausea, fatigue.

questions.question: Emphysema is
options: Due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of bronchial glands
An airway disease Page 56 of 203 STATE EXAMS 8
questions.explanation: Emphysema primarily affects alveoli (parenchyma).

questions.question: Circulatory shock can best be described as a condition in which there is
options: Loss of consciousness due to blood loss
Inadequate blood flow to meet the metabolic needs of the body tissues
questions.explanation: Shock = inadequate tissue perfusion.

questions.question: Causes of hypovolemic shock include
options: Vomiting and los of body fluids
questions.explanation: Hypovolemia from vomiting/diarrhoea/bleeding causes shock.

questions.question: Early signs of hypovolemic shock include
options: Restlessness, thirst, and increased heart rate
Increase in heart rate and increased pulse pressure
questions.explanation: Early signs: restlessness, thirst, tachycardia.

questions.question: In shock, one of the best indicators of blood flow to vital organs is
options: Rate of blood and fluid administration
questions.explanation: Severe shock: hypotension, rapid weak pulse, cold clammy skin.

questions.question: Oliguria, an early sign of shock, occurs for what reason
questions.explanation: Compensation increases arterial CO₂ due to hypoventilation; O₂ tension decreases.

questions.question: A person admitted to the emergency room with trauma and an estimated blood loss of 1200 to 1400 mls has a blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. The best explanation for these observations would be that
options: The persons actual blood loss was less than the originally estimated loss
The person was normally hypertensive and hence did not have as great a drop in blood pressure as a normotensive person
The cause of the bleeding is now under control and the increased heart rate is due to anxiety
An increase in heart rate is compensating for the loss of blood volume
questions.explanation: Cheyne–Stokes = periodic respiration with apnoea.

questions.question: The pale, cool, clammy skin that is often observed in an individual with shock, can be explained in terms of
options: Body‟s attempt to shunt blood to vital organs by constricting skin vessels
Decreased metabolic needs that accompany shock
Body‟s attempt to conserve heat loss Page 57 of 203
questions.explanation: COPD tends toward CO₂ retention → respiratory acidosis.

questions.question: ____________________ is generally relieved by sitting up in a forward leaning position
questions.explanation: Dyspnoea on exertion is a common early symptom.

questions.question: In a client with emphysema, hypoventilation could initially cause
questions.explanation: Hypoventilation causes CO₂ retention → respiratory acidosis.

questions.question: A client is anxious and is hyperventilating. In order to prevent respiratory alkalosis the nurse will
options: Have the client breathe deeply and slowly
Have the client breathe into a paper bag
questions.explanation: Rebreathe into paper bag to increase CO₂ and prevent alkalosis.

questions.question: A district nurse is sent to assess a new client with cor pulmonale. This term refers to
options: Giant bullae growth on the lung
questions.explanation: Cor pulmonale = right ventricular enlargement secondary to lung disease.

questions.question: Tony buffer, 54 years old, has a long history of smoking. He decides to have lung and blood studies done because he is very tired, is short of breath, and just does not feel good. His blood gases reveal the following findings: pH 7.3; HCO3 27; CO2 58. Tony's condition may be
questions.explanation: COPD exacerbation commonly shows respiratory acidosis.

questions.question: Approximately 1000ml (1L) of oxygen is transported to cells each minute. Most of the oxygen is transported
questions.explanation: Most O₂ transported bound to haemoglobin.

questions.question: Mary a 46 year old woman, is admitted to your ward with a chest infection due to an exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. A person with emphysema is susceptible to respiratory infections primarily because
options: Failure of his bone marrow to produce phagocytic white blood cells
Decreased detoxification of body fluids by compressed liver cells
Persistent mouth breathing associated with dyspnoea Page 58 of 203
questions.explanation: Emphysema predisposes to infection due to retained secretions and impaired clearance.

questions.question: Emphysema differs from chronic bronchitis in that
options: Emphysema obstruction results from mucous production and inflammation
Emphysema obstruction results from changes in lung tissues
Chronic bronchitis obstruction results from changes in lung tissue
There are no visual difference between the two conditions
questions.explanation: Emphysema obstruction arises from parenchymal tissue destruction (loss of elastic recoil).

questions.question: The tissue change most characteristic of emphysema is
options: Accumulation of pus in the pleural space
Constriction of capillaries by fibrous tissue
Filling of air passages by inflammatory coagulum
Over distension, in elasticity, and rupture of alveoli
questions.explanation: Emphysema features destruction of alveolar walls and loss of elastic recoil.

questions.question: Which of the following results of emphysema is primarily responsible for cardiomegaly
options: Hypertrophy of muscles encircling the bronchi
Increased pressure in the pulmonary circulation
Decreased number of circulating red blood cells
Secretion of excessive amounts of pericardial fluids
questions.explanation: During angina, rest reduces myocardial oxygen demand (plus nitrates).

questions.question: A 48 year old complains of chest pain. Signs and symptoms that would support a diagnosis of myocardial infarction would include
options: Fever and petechiae over the chest area
Nausea and vomiting and cool, clammy pale skin
Pericardial friction rub and absent apical pulse
questions.explanation: Acute MI often presents with N/V and cool, clammy skin (sympathetic response).

questions.question: Teaching for the client taking GT or glycerol with nitrate for angina would include
options: Instructing the client to take the nitro-glycerine regularly
Explain to the client that a subsequent headache indicates ineffective medication
Instructing the client to put the tablet on the tongue and swallow after the tablet dissolves
Teaching the client to take a tablet every 5 minutes (3x) when chest pain occurs
questions.explanation: Standard: 1 GTN tablet every 5 minutes up to 3 doses.

questions.question: A female client is diagnosed with unstable angina. The nurse finds her crying because she fears she will become a burden to her husband. Which of the following nursing diagnosis would be most appropriate
questions.explanation: Unstable angina often provokes anxiety/fear; address knowledge deficits to reduce fear.

questions.question: Which of the following steps should a client with periodic angina pain take first when pain occurs at home
options: Take sublingual nitro-glycerine and lie down
Take an extra long lasting nitrate tablet
Sit down and relax Page 59 of 203
questions.explanation: First action for angina at home: stop activity, sit/lie, take SL GTN.

questions.question: The nurse detects premature ventricular contractions and (PVC‟s) on the ECG of a client who had a mitral valve replacement 2 days ago. PVC‟s may be dangerous because they
options: May lead to ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation
Are the most common cause of myocardial infarction
Decreased heart rate and blood pressure
questions.explanation: PVCs can degenerate into VT/VF, especially post-op.

questions.question: A client is admitted to ED following a car accident. He complains of abdominal discomfort. The nurse encourages the client to lie down. The reason for this action is
options: To decrease the risk of dislodging an intra abdominal clot
To decrease the risk of peritoneal infection
questions.explanation: Supine reduces risk of dislodging intra-abdominal clots and bleeding.

questions.question: A client sustained moderate concussion. He has a Glasgow coma scale score of 7. Which of the following interventions would you include in your care plan
options: Decrease stimuli, monitor vital signs and neurological status nurse him flat on his back
Gradually increase stimuli, monitor vital signs and neurological status, elevate the head of the bed 60 degrees
Encourage family involvement, reduce monitoring at night to allow client to rest, elevate the head of the bed 60 degrees
Decrease stimuli, monitor vital signs and neurological status elevate the head of the bed 30 degrees, positioning the client on his side
questions.explanation: Referred pain from shoulder/abdomen ⇒ inspect abdomen/thorax.

questions.question: James has sustained a fracture of his left lower leg in a car accident. Classical signs of a fracture may include
options: Intermittent pain, flushing of surrounding tissues and vascular spasm
Local bone tenderness, soft tissue swelling and inability to use extremity
Neural compromise, sharp stabbing pain and obvious ischaemia of the extremity
questions.explanation: Multiple fractures of ribs → flail chest.

questions.question: Monitoring for compartment syndrome is done by checking for
options: Colour, warmth, sensation and movement of the extremity
The tightness of the plaster cast
questions.explanation: Le Fort fracture = midface fracture—common with facial trauma.

questions.question: On assessment the nurse suspects that James is developing compartment syndrome because he complains of
options: Severe pain, motor compromise and a „pins and needles‟ sensation
A radiating pain and loss of two point discrimination
Swelling, muscle atrophy and intermittent parasthesia
Dull aching, spasms and lack of fine co ordination
questions.explanation: Renal failure leads to metabolic acidosis; respiratory alkalosis develops with hyperventilation.

questions.question: A comminuted fracture is characterised by
options: A partial break in bone continuity
Injury in which two bones are crushed together
An injury in which the bone is broken into two or more pieces Page 60 of 203
An injury in which the bone fragments have broken through the skin
questions.explanation: Comminuted fracture: bone broken into several pieces.

questions.question: Type 2 diabetics
options: Are usually very slim and malnourished
questions.explanation: Type 2 DM may be insidious for years.

questions.question: Hyperglycemia
options: Is alright only once in a while
Due to an over medication of insulin
If left uncontrolled, this can lead to DKA in type 1 or HNK in type 2
questions.explanation: Uncontrolled hyperglycaemia leads to DKA (type 1) or HHS/HNK (type 2).

questions.question: Macrovascular complications of diabetes
options: Occur shortly after the onset of the disease
Affects coronary, peripheral and cerebral circulation
Affects the eyes and the kidneys
questions.explanation: Macrovascular complications involve coronary, peripheral, cerebral vessels.

questions.question: For relief of angina, the client may
options: Take a dose of glyceryl trinitrate up to 3 times, 5 minutes apart until the pain subsides
Slowly exercise to the individuals tolerance level
Take only one dose of glyceryl trinitrate, if this has no effect, call 111
questions.explanation: GTN up to 3 doses at 5-min intervals; call emergency if persists.

questions.question: Ways to minimise precipitating effects of angina are
questions.explanation: Avoid overexertion, stress, and overeating to reduce angina.

questions.question: Angina
options: May be referred to as angina majoralis
Include chest pain which may radiate down the arms, neck, jaw and back
questions.explanation: Sudden blurring with headache = raised ICP—urgent assessment.

questions.question: A client with multiple fractures is at risk for a fat embolism. What early sign should you monitor for
options: Pallor and discoloration at the fracture site
questions.explanation: Symptoms of raised ICP: headache, vomiting, LOC changes.

questions.question: Following an application of a full arm cast a client complains of deep throbbing elbow pain. You note diminished capillary refill in the fingers. You should
options: Notify the doctor immediately and prepare to bivalve the cast
Cut a window in the cast over the elbow area and check for infection Page 61 of 203
Elevate the arm, apply ice packs and assess hourly
Administer prescribed analgesics and notify the doctor
questions.explanation: Battle’s sign/Raccoon eyes signify basilar skull fracture.

questions.question: When assessing a patient at risk for increased intracranial pressure, the first thing you would check is
questions.explanation: Blown pupil suggests uncal herniation → urgent intervention.

questions.question: Pupillary dilation occurs when herniating brain tissue
questions.explanation: Papilloedema is optic disc swelling from raised ICP—does not paralyse ocular muscles.

questions.question: Changes in vital signs with increasing intracranial pressure would include
questions.explanation: Cushing’s triad: widened pulse pressure + bradycardia + irregular respirations.

questions.question: Bleeding within the skull results in increased intracranial pressure because
options: Spinal fluid is produced more rapidly
The cranium is a closed, rigid vault
questions.explanation: Skull is a rigid vault; any bleed raises ICP.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of heart failure (HF)
questions.explanation: CAD is the most common cause of HF.

questions.question: The action of ACE inhibitors (angiotensin converting enzyme) is
options: Increased urinary output, therefore decreased blood pressure
Relax blood vessels, therefore decreased vascular resistance
Strengthens cardiac contraction, therefore increase cardiac output
Relax cardiac muscle therefore decrease heart rate
questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors vasodilate → ↓afterload/↓vascular resistance.

questions.question: Hyperkalemia is
questions.explanation: Hyperkalaemia = high serum K⁺.

questions.question: Manifestations of heart failure are
options: Increased serum glucose levels Page 62 of 203
questions.explanation: SA node is heart’s pacemaker.

questions.question: Nursing interventions associated with your clients taking loop diuretics such as frusemide are
options: Monitoring of weight and K+ levels
Make sure your client eats ½ hour following administration
questions.explanation: SA node initiates heartbeat.

questions.question: Loop diuretics act by
options: Increasing the blood flow to the glomerular network
Decreasing the blood flow to the kidneys therefore decreased urinary output
Increased H2O reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules of the nephron
Inhibition complex active pump mechanism therefore increase excretion of electrolytes
questions.explanation: Baroreceptors detect pressure changes.

questions.question: Blood pressure control is carried out by regulation of smooth muscles via
questions.explanation: Sinoatrial node location: right atrial wall near SVC.

questions.question: The areas of the body that sense blood pressure are known as
questions.explanation: Nociceptors detect tissue damage/pain.

questions.question: When taking a blood pressure, the first sound picked up by the stethoscope as blood pulses through the artery is the
questions.explanation: First Korotkoff sound corresponds to systolic BP.

questions.question: At any given moment, the systemic circulation contains about _________________ of the total blood volume
questions.explanation: Systemic circulation holds ~70% of blood volume.

questions.question: The nurse gets the arterial blood gases report and it shows that a person has hypercapnia. This means that
options: There is an increased blood carbon dioxide
The blood oxygen level is reduced
There is respiratory alkalosis Page 63 of 203
questions.explanation: Hypercapnia = elevated CO₂ in blood.

questions.question: Gregory, aged 70, was admitted with congestive heart failure. Which of these changes in physiology is present in congestive heart failure
options: Heart muscle degeneration due to old age
A decrease of blood flow through the heart
An abnormality in the structure of the heart
A blood clot forms in one of the heart chambers
questions.explanation: CHF involves decreased forward blood flow.

questions.question: Manifestations of right sided heart failure are
options: Anorexia, complaints of gastrointestinal distress, fatigue and pitted edema
questions.explanation: Right HF: GI symptoms, anorexia, fatigue, peripheral oedema.

questions.question: Nursing intervention necessary prior to the administration of digoxin is
options: Palpation of arterial pulse less than 60 bpm
Palpation of venous pulse less than 60 bpm
Palpation of arterial pulse greater than 60 bpm
Palpation of pedal pulse less than 60 bpm
questions.explanation: Stable angina: predictable with exertion; acute MI at rest more likely CHD.

questions.question: Left sided heart failure affects directly the
questions.explanation: Bronchitis commonly with smoking and pollutants.

questions.question: Basic nursing objectives in the treatment of HF are
options: Nursing the client in trendlenberg position
Promote rest therefore decrease workload on heart and decrease H20 accumulation
Assess levels of consciousness and give 02 61/min via Hudson mask
questions.explanation: Highest risk in 40–60 years for CHD due to cumulative risk factors.

questions.question: Define a cerebral vascular accident (CVA)
options: Sudden loss of consciousness due to a decreased contractility of the cardia
Loss of brain function due to disruption of blood supply to the brain
Intermittent spasms of blood vessels interrupting blood flow to the brain
Neurologic dysfunction due to diminished blood flow to the cranium
questions.explanation: Stroke due to cerebrovascular occlusion—arterial spasm is less typical cause.

questions.question: Cerebral thrombosis is
options: Most common cause of a stroke
Originates from a large vessel and lodges in the brain
May be caused by an arterial spasm in the brain
questions.explanation: Women often have atypical MI symptoms, but chest pain/pressure remains common.

questions.question: The term blue bloater refers to
options: Decreased erythropoietin production therefore decreased 02 carrying capability of the RBC
Polycythemia and cyanosis from right ventricular failure
Cyanosis due to decreased RBC production Page 64 of 203
Increased BP due to high blood volume or fluid overload
questions.explanation: Blue bloater describes chronic bronchitis with cyanosis/polycythaemia/RV failure.

questions.question: Bronchitis is
options: Results from a breakdown in the normal lung defence mechanisms
Due to enlarged terminal non respiratory bronchioles and alveolar walls
History of daily productive cough that last at least 3 months, for 2 years
questions.explanation: Chronic bronchitis: productive cough ≥3 months/year for 2 consecutive years.

questions.question: Emphysema is characterised by
options: Fat people due to decreased activity tolerance
Unproductive cough and pursed lip breathing
Pursed lip breathing and productive cough
Blue bloater, normal skin colour and rapid respirations
questions.explanation: Emphysema: pursed-lip breathing, usually minimal cough (unproductive).

questions.question: Nursing interventions for the CORD patient include everyone of these except
options: Promote cooperation and understanding e) Encourage exercise to test tolerance levels
questions.explanation: Do not „encourage exercise to test tolerance‟ in acute CORD/COPD exacerbation.

questions.question: Bronchodilators
options: Liquefy the sputum therefore increase expectoration
Include aminophylline for the acute exacerbation
Are only used in emergency cases
questions.explanation: Aminophylline may be used for acute bronchodilation.

questions.question: Corticosteroids are used
options: To aid in vitamin D synthesis
To aid the liquefaction and expectoration of sputum
Used during the acute exacerbation of CORD
questions.explanation: Bronchodilators improve alveolar ventilation and gas exchange.

questions.question: Pursed lip and diaphragmatic breathing
options: Speed up slow respirations and used to promote effective coughing
Prevents bronchiolar collapse and air trapping
Encourages longer inhalation and faster exhalation
