questions.explanation: Provide structure and gentle, firm guidance for basic self-care in mania/psychosis.

questions.question: Claire lost 15lb last week and now weights 100lb. the nurse formulates a nursing diagnosis based on the diagnostic category altered nutrition: less than body requirements. Which goal is most appropriate initially
options: The patient will consume an adequate diet
The patient will maintain her current weight of 100lb
The patient will gain 1lb per week
The patient will remain adequately hydrated
questions.explanation: 1g=1000mg; 120mg=0.12g = 120,000 mcg; question likely µg conversion.

questions.question: Claire's hydration and nutrition needs would be to
options: Leave finger foods and liquids in her room and let her eat and drink as she moves about Page 82 of 203
Bring her to the dining room and encourage her to sit and eat with calm, quiet companions
Explain meal time routines and allow her to make own decisions about eating
Provide essential nutrition through high calorie gavage (naso gastric) feedings
questions.explanation: Ceiling fixtures reduce risk; maintain safe environment for confused patient.

questions.question: The physician decides to start Claire on lithium therapy. Which of the following best describes her dietary requirements while she is receiving this medication
options: A high calorie diet with reduced sodium and adequate fluid intake
A regular diet with normal sodium and adequate intake
A low calorie diet with reduced sodium and increased fluid intake
A regular diet with reduced sodium and adequate fluid intake
questions.explanation: 30 mL urine indicates oliguria.

questions.question: Michelle aged 25 is found sitting on the floor of the bathroom in treatment clinic with moderate lacerations to both wrists. Accompanied with broken glass she sits staring blankly at her bleeding wrists while staff members call for an ambulance. How should the nurse approach Michelle initially
options: Enter the room quietly and move beside Michelle to assess her injuries
Call for staff backup before entering the room and restraining Michelle
Move as much glass away from Michelle as possible and quietly sit next to her
Approach Michelle slowly while speaking in a calm voice, calling her name and telling her that the nurse is here to help her
questions.explanation: Acknowledge feelings; avoid false reassurance.

questions.question: Michelle is taken to the hospital and admitted on an emergency basis for 5 days compulsory assessment and treatment. Michelle says to the admitting nurse. I‟m not staying here. I was a little upset and did a stupid thing. I want to leave. Which response is most appropriate
options: Unfortunately, you have no right to leave at this time. You must be evaluated further
Cutting your wrists certainly was a stupid thing to do. What were you trying to accomplish anyway
You have been admitted on an emergency basis and can be held you have the right to consult a lawyer about your admission
I can see you‟re upset. Why don‟t you try to relax. You can explain to the doctor what upset you. If what you say is true, you‟ll be released sooner.
questions.explanation: Patient’s autonomous right to refuse; document and inform physician.

questions.question: Determining michelles suicide potential during the mental status examination, involves assessing several factors, the most significant of which is her
questions.explanation: Prevent falls: rails up; document safety measures.

questions.question: Michelle is placed on suicide precautions, which include constant observation. When the nurse accompanies her to the bathroom. Michelle complains, I can‟t believe this. I can‟t even go to the bathroom without being watched. How would you like to have me watching you go to the toilet. Which response by the nurse is best
options: I‟m sure I wouldn‟t like it very much, but then I didn‟t try to hurt myself
I‟m sorry but these are the rules. Someone must be with you at all times
If it‟s more comfortable for you, I can stand right outside as long as the door is open. Would you agree to that Page 83 of 203
I would probably feel uncomfortable too, but ensuring your safety is my first priority. I must stay in the room with you
questions.explanation: Chronic illness patients: anxiety and depression common.

questions.question: 5 days of hospitalization. Michelle is to be discharged and an outpatient basis at the day of treatment clinic. During discharge planning, the nurse should set as a priority short term goals Michelle will
options: Identify support systems to help manage stress
Verbalise feelings of shame regarding her suicide attempt
Demonstrate an uplifted mood and optimism about the future
Admit that her wrist slashing was an attention seeking behaviour and not a true suicide attempt
questions.explanation: Encourage rest between activities for elderly fatigue.

questions.question: Upon transfer to the psychiatric unit Megan is informed by the admitting nurse that it will be necessary to check her belongings for any unsafe or banned items. She begins to scream angrily. What‟s the matter with you. I‟m upset. Get away from me. The nurse should first
options: Place Megan in seclusion and restraints
Eliminate the belongings search so as to avoid upsetting her
Set verbal limits on her behaviour
questions.explanation: Vision/skin changes are normal ageing; orient to environment for safety.

questions.question: Megan requests a weekend pass two days after transfer to the psychiatric unit. Her primary nurse informs her following the treatment team meeting that the pass has not been approved. Megan responds angrily. They all hate me, they‟re so mean. I know you‟d have let me go. You‟re the only decent nurse here. The nurses best response is
options: I would have approved it, but you‟re right I‟m only one voice
I don‟t think the others realise how hard you‟ve been trying
Megan you‟ll never get a pass behaving this way
This was the teams‟ decision. Let‟s talk about why we feel it‟s not appropriate now
questions.explanation: Correct BP cuff size critical for accuracy.

questions.question: Megan‟s behaviour in this situation illustrates the use of which defence mechanism
questions.explanation: Turn cough deep-breathe to prevent atelectasis/pneumonia.

questions.question: Megan‟s doctor resumes her regular dosage of amitriptyline. Which effect of this medication might the staff and patient expect to see first
questions.explanation: Advance from clear fluids as tolerated after GI surgery.

questions.question: Wilfred a 42 year old executive, is admitted for treatment of his alcoholism. The most important factor in Wilfred‟s rehabilitation is
options: The qualitative level of his physical state
His familys' accepting attitude Page 84 of 203
questions.explanation: Report signs of infection at wound site (redness, warmth).

questions.question: Which one of the following remarks of Wilfred, made prior to discharge from hospital would show the most realistic assessment of his situation in relation to avoiding future drinking problems
options: I promise I‟ll never get drunk again
I will cut down my drinking so I drink only socially
I can stop drinking providing my wife keeps off my back
I‟m going to try hard to stay away from that first drink
questions.explanation: Foot drop prevented by dorsiflexion splint/footboard positioning.

questions.question: John is a 32 year old man with a 5 year history of psychiatric admissions. He is escorted to the mental health unit by the police. He is dishevelled, confused and his records state that he has been diagnosed as chronic undifferentiated schizophrenic. The nurse observes john sitting in the hall looking frightened. He is curled up in a corner of the bench with his arms over his head and covering his face. How should the nurse approach the patient
options: Walk over to the bench, sit beside him quietly, and place an arm around his shoulders, then say I‟m the nurse and wait for a response
Allow him to remain alone on the bench, where he can observe the unit for a half hour or so until he is more comfortable
Greet him warmly saying hi I‟m the nurse. This is a very nice unit. I think you‟ll like it here. Let me show you around
Sit about 3 or 4 feet from him on the bench and say hello john I‟m a nurse on this unit. You appear frightened then wait for a response
questions.explanation: Ask open-ended, nonthreatening question and wait—D is best.

questions.question: John responds to the nurse by curling up on the bench even tighter. His arms still cover his head and his hands are clasped tightly over his ears. The nurse should
options: Show acceptance of johns behaviour by remaining with him and reassuring him, gently stroking his arms and shoulders
Tell john that she will leave him for a while and will return later when he feels more relaxed
Say gently john ill just sit here quietly with you for a while then remain seated nearby
Say john, most people feel uncomfortable in hospitals. You shouldn‟t be afraid. I‟m here to help you
questions.explanation: Sit quietly nearby—conveys presence without intrusion.

questions.question: Later that evening, the nurse finds john crouched in the corner of his room, with a curtain covering him. His roommate is sitting on the bed laughing and saying this guy is really a nut. He should be in a padded cell. How should the nurse respond to the roommate
options: Say I‟m sure John's behaviour is frightening to you. I understand that you are trying to cover up how you really feel by laughing
Say id appreciate it if you‟d step outside for awhile. I‟d like to talk with you after I help john
Say nothing and attend to john
Say in a neutral tone. I think your laughing is making john feel worse. How would you feel if you were john
questions.explanation: Name the behaviour’s impact neutrally; set boundaries respectfully.

questions.question: What is the least threatening approach to john while he sits huddled under the curtain Page 85 of 203
options: Sit next to him on the floor without speaking, and wait for him to acknowledge the nurse
Gently remove the curtain and say, john this is the nurse. What happened
Approach john slowly and say. John this is the nurse. You appear to be very frightened. Can you tell me what you are experiencing
Call for assistance and do not approach john until at least two other staff members are present
questions.explanation: Approach slowly, acknowledge fear, and invite sharing experience.

questions.question: Because john has previously responded well to treatment with haloperidol (serenace), the doctor orders haloperidol 10mg orally twice a day. Which adverse effect is most common with this medication
questions.explanation: Haloperidol commonly causes drowsiness/sedation initially.

questions.question: During the next several days, john is observed laughing, yelling and talking to himself. His behaviour is characteristic of
questions.explanation: Laughing/talking to self = auditory hallucinations (not illusions).

questions.question: John tells the nurse, the earth is doomed, you know. The ozone is being destroyed by hair spray. You should get away before you die. John appears frightened as he say this. The most helpful response is to
options: Say john I think you are overreacting. I know that some concern about the earth‟s ozone layer, but there is no immediate danger to anyone
Say I‟ve heard about the destruction of the ozone and its effect on the earth. Why don‟t you tell me more about it
Ignore johns statement and redirect his attention to activity on the unit
Say john are you saying you feel as though sometimes will happen to you. I don‟t believe we are in danger right now
questions.explanation: Aggression may be due to internal stimuli; remove audience and reduce stimulation.

questions.question: After a half hour, john continues to ramble about the ozone layer being doomed to die. He paces in an increasingly agitated mood he begins to speak more loudly. At this time, the nurse should
options: Check to see whether the doctor ordered haloperidol
Allow john to continue pacing but observe him closely
Try to involve john in a current events discussion group that is about to start
Tell john to go to his room for a while
questions.explanation: Assault risk: get help and ensure safety before approaching.

questions.question: Henry is brought to the mental health unit by his wife who states for the past week her husband has refused all meals and accused her of poisoning him, he has become withdrawn, forgetful and inattentive and has frequent mood swings. Henry appears suspicious. His speech which is only partly comprehensible reveals that his thoughts are controlled by delusions of possession by the devil. He claims the devil told him that people around him are trying to destroy him. The doctor diagnoses paranoid schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is best described as a disorder characterised by
options: Disturbed relationships related to an inability to communicate and think clearly Page 86 of 203
Severe mood swings and periods of low to high activity
Multiple personalities, one of which is more destructive than the others
questions.explanation: Delusion of persecution: fear others plotting harm; reality test gently.

questions.question: The nursing assessment of Henry should include careful observation of his
options: Thinking, perceiving and decisions making skills
questions.explanation: ECT indicated for severe depression when meds fail or rapid response needed.

questions.question: When communicating with Henry the nurse should initially
options: Remain silent and wait for Henry to speak first
Talk with Henry as one would talk with a healthy person
Allow Henry to do all the talking
Speak to Henry using simple, concrete language
questions.explanation: Pregnancy protein needs increase.

questions.question: The patients thought content can be evaluated on the basis of which assessment area
options: Unbiased information from the patients psychiatric history
Degree of orientation to person, place and time
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency anaemia common in pregnancy.

questions.question: Henry mentions that voices are telling him that he is in danger and that he will be safe only if he stays in his room and avoids „zoids‟. How should the nurse respond
options: I understand that these voices are real to you, but I want you to know that I do not here them
Don‟t worry. I won‟t let anything happen to you here
What else can you tell me about the voices
Many patients hear voices when they come here. The voices will go away when you get better
questions.explanation: Best to avoid known allergens/irritants in asthma.

questions.question: The innermost layer of the eye is
questions.explanation: Status asthmaticus requires immediate medical attention.

questions.question: The nurse observes Henry pacing in his room. He is alone but in an angry tone. When asked what he was experiencing he replies the devil is yelling in my ear. He say people here want to live. The nurses best response is
options: Can you tell me more about what the devil is saying
How do you feel when the devil says such things to you
I don‟t hear any voice. Henry are you feeling afraid now
Henry the devil cannot talk to you
questions.explanation: Asthma: expiratory wheeze common.

questions.question: Mary is admitted under section 11 of the mental health (compulsory assessment and treatment act 1992). The definition of mental disorder under the act includes all of the following except
options: A seriously diminished ability to care for yourself
An abnormal state of mind Page 87 of 203
A serious danger to self or others
questions.explanation: Dyspnoea and chest tightness notable asthma signs.

questions.question: Marys rights under the act include, the right
options: To information about her status, to respect of her culture identity, to seek legal representation
To respect as a human being, to respect of her cultural values, to receive visitors and make phone calls
To information about her status, to receive treatment to health care, to change her treatment at her request
To receive visitors and make telephone calls, to refuse seclusion on cultural grounds, to seek a judicial inquiry
questions.explanation: Embryo implants in endometrium by day 6–7; hormone changes.

questions.question: Mary asks for review of her legal status. Your action would be
options: Explain that her status will be reviewed by the responsible clinician before the end of five days
Reassure her that you understand how frustrating it must to be in hospital against her will
Offer to phone the client advocate on Marys behalf
Explain section 16 to Mary and allow her to phone the district inspector
questions.explanation: First trimester breast tenderness is normal; support bra helps.

questions.question: Under section 30 of the mental health act (1992), the inpatient treatment order lasts for
questions.explanation: Prenatal nausea: small frequent meals, avoid greasy foods.

questions.question: Under section 111 of the mental health act (1992) a person admitted to hospital, not already subject to any assessment and treatment can be detained, for how long, if considered mentally disordered
questions.explanation: Balanced diet, iron/folate supplementation for pregnancy nutrition.

questions.question: Lisa tell the nurse that she has gained 2kg in a month and plans to diet by skipping lunches. Which of the following responses would be the most appropriate
options: Have you noticed that your hands and feet have become swollen
You should cut down on high calorie foods like cake and candy, but you shouldn‟t skip lunch
Your weight gain is just right for you for this period of your pregnancy. You are doing fine
You‟re supposed to gain a lot of weight its good for the baby. You‟ll lose it after the baby is born
questions.explanation: Appropriate weight gain reassurance is therapeutic.

questions.question: 50mg is equal to
questions.explanation: 50 mg = 50,000 micrograms.

questions.question: The drugs used to treat Parkinson‟s disease act by
options: Increasing cholinergic activity and increasing dopamine
Reducing cholinergic activity and increasing dopamine
Increasing cholinergic activity and reducing dopamine
Reducing cholinergic activity and reducing dopamine
questions.explanation: Parkinson drugs reduce ACh and increase dopamine effects.

questions.question: Recent research indicates that arthritis may be an autoimmune disease. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the process of autoimmunity
options: A rare complication of vaccination when the body reacts to the vaccine by producing symptoms of the disease
An inherent factor in the blood which renders the person susceptible to certain diseases
Lack of antitoxins in the blood which render the person susceptible to the certain diseases
Formation of antibodies in the blood which destroy certain healthy cells in the individual
questions.explanation: Autoimmunity: antibodies attack self tissue.

questions.question: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis commonly have a raised ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate). This is because
options: Arthritic patients usually have a degree of anaemia
Rheumatoid factor decreases the viscosity of the cells
Protein changes result in the erythrocytes becoming heavier
There is an increase in leukocyte numbers
questions.explanation: Protein changes increase rouleaux formation → raised ESR.

questions.question: Before administering a dose of digoxin the patients pulse (apex beat) should be taken. Which is the correct action for the nurse to take if the pulse is found to be under 60 beats per minute
options: Give the drug and take the pulse again an hour later
Give the drug and notify the staff nurse that the pulse is slow
Do not give the drug and report the slow pulse to the doctor
Omit the drug and make a note on the nursing care plan
questions.explanation: Hold digoxin if apical <60 and notify doctor.

questions.question: Which of the following can be causes of anaemia in the elderly 1. Apathy and depression 2. Ill fitting dentures 3. A physiological inability to utilize food properly
questions.explanation: Swallowing intact: use straw? But safest: observe and give sips of water first—option C 'test with sips of water'.

questions.question: Old people are inevitably a burden on the community (assertion) because old people cannot work because they are slow and cannot be relied on (reason). With reference to the above statement which of the following is true
options: Both assertion and reason are true statements but the reason is not a correct explanation of assertion
The assertion is true but the reason is a false statement
The assertion is false but the reason is a true statement
Both the assertion and reason are false statements Page 89 of 203
questions.explanation: Life-threatening adverse effect of aminophylline is arrhythmia.

questions.question: A common problem with the elderly is their reluctance to drink adequate amounts of fluid. The most probable reason for this is that they are
options: More likely to sweat than younger people
questions.explanation: Pulse pressure = systolic − diastolic.

questions.question: Haemorrhage into the anterior chamber of the eye following a cataract extraction is called
questions.explanation: Hypocalcaemia → tetany (Chvostek/Trousseau).

questions.question: Mrs Adams suffers from dementia and requires a dressing to a shin wound. The nurse suspects the wound is the result of a non accidental injury. What is the main cause of non accidental injury in an elderly person suffering from dementia
options: A dependent person being more prone to injury
A long standing pattern of domestic violence
The home not being a suitable place for a dependent person
The increased stress in caring for a dependent person at home
questions.explanation: Thrush: white patches that can be wiped, leaving raw surface.

questions.question: When dressing the shin wound the nurses most appropriate remark is
options: How did you scrape your shin Mrs. Adams
How did you scrape your wife‟s shin Mr. Adams
This shin must hurt. Was it really an accident
A shin is easy to hurt. How did this injury happen
questions.explanation: Tinea pedis = athlete’s foot (fungal).

questions.question: The most appropriate way to help Mr. and Mrs. Adams at the first visit is to
options: Express professional concern at the cause of the injury
Conceal feelings about the possible cause of the injury
Reassure Mrs. Adams that this injury will not occur again
Acknowledge the stress of Mr. Adams in caring for his wife
questions.explanation: Psoriasis shows silvery scales/plaques; treatments include tar, UV.

questions.question: An increased incidence of vaginal infections occurs when contraceptive pills are taken because there is
options: A shift in the vaginal pH
A reduction in white cell numbers
questions.explanation: Impetigo is contagious bacterial skin infection with honey crusts.

questions.question: What action should the nurse take when on three home visits the mother of a nine months old baby prevents him from being seen as „he is sleeping‟
options: Notify the social welfare of the situation
Notify the family doctor in writing of this occurrence
Insist on seeing the child and refuse to leave the home
Respect the patients right to accept or refuse treatment
questions.explanation: Heat stroke: hot dry skin, hyperthermia.

questions.question: Which is the major pathophysiological abnormality occurring in asthma Page 90 of 203
options: Spasm of the smooth muscles of the bronchi
questions.explanation: Peripheral vascular disease: absent pulses, pallor, pain.

questions.question: Which of the following sings/symptoms would indicate mumps
questions.explanation: Measles (rubeola) is highly contagious via droplets/airborne.

questions.question: Which option is important for the nurse to know with regard to prevention of the spread of mumps
options: Safe disposal of all bodily excretions
No specific isolation measures are needed
Control of all food stuffs prepared for sale
Isolation for ten days after the last notified case
questions.explanation: Aseptic technique: prevent contamination during procedures.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best description of a vaccine
questions.explanation: Overdose: threat to life—maintain airway.

questions.question: Mrs Shaw brings her 8 year old daughter Jane to the clinic. Jane has eczema. Jane‟s eczema is most likely the result of
options: Excretion of acids through sweat pores
An inherited predisposition to skin infections
Sensitivity to a substance in her external environment
questions.explanation: Scabies: intense pruritus at night in webs of fingers.

questions.question: Eczema is the term used to describe a (n)
options: Acute, contagious inflammation of the skin
Non contagious inflammatory response of the skin
Fungal infection more commonly seen in childhood
Condition marked by the appearance of erythematous wheals
questions.explanation: Ringworm (tinea corporis) is fungal infection of skin.

questions.question: Which statement best describes „vesicle‟
options: Small area of swelling on the skin
Small blister filled with serous fluid
questions.explanation: Vesicle: small, serous fluid-filled blister.

questions.question: You are employed as a practice nurse. A friend telephones and asks if her boyfriend has been to see the doctor this week. Your most appropriate response is
options: I‟ll have to ask the doctor
I am not able to tell you that
Just a moment, ill check the files Page 91 of 203
questions.explanation: Confidentiality: cannot disclose appointment details.

questions.question: Aminophylline 350mg is prescribed. Each ampoule contains 250mg in 10ml. how much should be added to the intravenous solution
questions.explanation: Need 350 mg; amps 250 mg/10 mL → 100 mg is 4 mL; 350 mg = 14 mL.

questions.question: Jillian‟s intravenous infusion of 300ml normal saline is due to run over 4 hours. The drop factor is 60. How many drops per minute must be given for the IV to be completed on time
questions.explanation: 300 mL over 4 h DF 25? Wait question says due in 3 hours with DF 25? Stem shows 300ml due in 4 hours? Given options: 75 dpm most likely.

questions.question: A client is charted nitrazepam (mogadon) tablets to sleep. She refuses to take them at 9pm. She tells you that the other nurses always leave the tablets on the locker and she takes them when she is ready. What should you do
options: Put them back in the container
Give her the tablets and let her take them later
Tell the patient to ring when she is ready for them
Tell her if she doesn‟t take them now she may not get them later
questions.explanation: Do not leave meds at bedside; tell patient to ring when ready.

questions.question: Hyperventilation may initially cause
questions.explanation: Insomnia management includes establishing a regular sleep schedule.

questions.question: Your neurologic assessment indicates increased ICP (intracranial pressure), so you raise the head of the bed 15 to 30 degrees in order to
options: Improve arterial flow to the brain
Promote venous drainage from the brain
questions.explanation: Unconscious: oral care includes suction and side-lying to prevent aspiration.

questions.question: Pulse pressure is defined as the
options: Pressure felt at the radial artery over the wrist
Pressure of the heart beating against arterial walls
Difference between the apical and radial pulses
Difference between the systolic and diastolic blood pressures STATE EXAMS 11
questions.explanation: Head-injury: check level of consciousness frequently.

questions.question: Mr March sixty year old farmer, was admitted to a private hospital for rehabilitation following a cerebro vascular accident which resulted in right sided hemiplegia. When cerebro vascular accident causes occlusion of blood supply to one area of the brain, loss of voluntary muscle control is usually evident on
options: The same side of the body as the brain damage Page 92 of 203
The opposite side of the body to the brain damage
The opposite side of the face
questions.explanation: Purpose of NGT: decompression, feeding, aspiration of gastric contents.

questions.question: Which of the following is most important for Mr. march to succeed in a rehabilitation programme
options: Knowledge of the services available to him
His relationships with the health team
questions.explanation: Airway obstruction: head tilt–chin lift (unless trauma).

questions.question: A rehabilitation programme for Mr. march should begin with
options: Utilising the movement he still has
questions.explanation: Back blows/chest thrusts for infants; abdominal thrusts for adults.

questions.question: There is evidence that Mr. March suffers a mild degree of expressive aphasia. This would be evidenced by which of the following behaviours
options: Mr march has difficulty in understanding what is spoken to him although he can verbally express his needs appropriately
Mr march has difficulty in both understanding what is spoken to him and in verbally communicating with others
Mr march understands what is spoken to him but has difficulty in forming and expressing words
Mr march has difficulty interpreting sensory stimuli causing him to respond inappropriately
questions.explanation: In oxygen therapy secure tank, check pressure, prevent sparks.

questions.question: Mr March is enthusiastic about his exercise programme. He exercises should be
options: Carried out in the physiotherapy department
questions.explanation: Mental health: document objectively; avoid judgmental language.

questions.question: A rehabilitation programme should promote
options: The best possible level of mobility and ambulation
questions.explanation: Narcotic poisoning: naloxone is antidote.

questions.question: While Mr. March is hospitalised, the nurse is concerned with preventing the complications of prolonged bed rest. Mr March already has a reddened area over the sacrum and coccyx. The nurse knows that the most important action to prevent a decubitus ulcer is to
options: Keep the skin area clean, dry and free from urine, faeces and perspiration
Place an alternating air pressure or water mattress on the bed
Massage the reddened area with lotion or oil to stimulate circulation
Turn and reposition the client at least q2h; avoid positioning him on the affected side if possible Page 93 of 203
questions.explanation: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant used for seizures/neuropathic pain.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most correct statement about positioning the stroke client
options: Flexor muscles are generally stronger than extensors
Extensor muscles are generally stronger than flexor
The fingers should be flexed tightly
The footboard should be flush with the mattress
questions.explanation: Parkinson’s: rigidity and tremor common.

questions.question: Mrs Sweetman, aged sixty two years has non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. She recently returned home from hospital where she received treatment for any infection of her left big toe. Mrs Sweetman's toe infection resulted from an injury of which she was unaware. The most likely reason for this would be that
options: She did not regularly wash her feet
She finds it difficult to flex her knees and hips
She has diminished sensation in her feet
questions.explanation: Post-MI rehab includes graded exercise, diet, smoking cessation.

questions.question: Mrs Sweetman‟s foot problems result from neuropathic, vascular and infectious changes. The most important feature of foot care should be
options: Inspect the feet daily and wash with mild soap and water
Maintain adequate blood flow to the lower limbs
Rub the feet with alcohol once a week
Avoid wearing garters of constricting shoes
questions.explanation: Communicable disease spreads from person to person.

questions.question: The first priority in caring for a person whose tissues have insufficient blood supply is to
options: Promote the development of collateral circulation
Protect the tissues from any injury
Relieve the pain associated with vasodilation
questions.explanation: Reinforcement follows a response and increases its probability.

questions.question: Peter aged 10 diagnosed as moderately mentally retarded. He lives in a IHC residence and attends a special school. You are employed as a carer at the residence. A major strategy in teaching peter is based on behaviour modification principles. An important element in peters management then is the use of reinforcement. Which statement best defines what a reinforce is for peter.
options: A reinforce is anything you think peter will enjoy
A reinforce is anything peter gains enjoyment from even if it appears to an observer to be producing pain
A reinforce is anything which precedes a response which is likely to increase the probability of that response occurring again
A reinforce is anything that follows a response that decreases the probability of that response occurring again
questions.explanation: A reinforcer increases probability; negative reinforcer removes aversive stimulus.

questions.question: You wish to teach peter to put on his pants. If the first step in his training programme was doing up his belt correctly. This method would best be described as
questions.explanation: Backward chaining: teach last step first for success reinforcement.

questions.question: When teaching peter to pull his pants up a physical prompt by guiding peters hand is used. As Peters' learning increases the physical prompt becomes no more than a gentle touch. This is an example of
questions.explanation: Fading: gradually reduce the intensity of prompt.

questions.question: Peter has a temper tantrum during which he lies on the floor at the entrance to the hallway. This is making it difficult for other residents. He has been asked to get up but continues his tantrum. Using the principles of extinction how would you deal with peter
options: Continuing to ask him in a firm voice to get up
Ignore him and instruct the other residents to step over him
Explain to him that he is blocking the entrance and it is unsafe for him to remain where he is
Let him know that if he doesn‟t get up immediately he will be punished
questions.explanation: Use extinction: ignore tantrum if safe; remove attention.

questions.question: What would be the most likely effect initially on peters behaviour when commencing to apply the principles of extinctions
questions.explanation: Extinction burst: behaviour worsens initially before improving.

questions.question: Peter has a habit of hugging new staff members and visitors to the residence. In order for extinction of this inappropriate social behaviour it would be necessary for him
options: Not to be punished for inappropriate behaviour
To be rewarded for inappropriate behaviour
To be punished for inappropriate behaviour
Not to receive reinforcement for this in appropriate behaviour
questions.explanation: Teach alternative appropriate greeting and reinforce it; do not punish hugging alone.

questions.question: If the staff were to apply the principles of response cost in dealing with peters inappropriate social behaviour they could do so by
options: Taking away something that peter found reinforcing such as restricting his TV viewing
Taking away from peter something that he found unpleasant such as having to eat his vegetables
Applying an aversive stimuli such as making him stay in his room
Ignoring the inappropriate behaviour but reinforcing an appropriate behaviour such as his willingness to help with the dishes
questions.explanation: Principles of behaviour change: reinforce successive approximations (shaping).

questions.question: Peter also suffers from epilepsy. During a seizure he falls to the ground is unconscious and begins to convulse. The best immediate response would be to
options: Cradle peters head in your lap
Place something in peters mouth to prevent him biting his tongue
Move him to a place of safety
questions.explanation: Developmental disability: promote independence in ADLs.

questions.question: Which of the following tests furnishes the best diagnostic information about seizures Page 95 of 203
questions.explanation: Task analysis breaks down skills into steps for teaching.

questions.question: Peter does not regain consciousness after his seizure, but after a brief pause in the convulsions the seizure continues. The term for this is called
questions.explanation: Use least restrictive alternative and positive reinforcement.

questions.question: Major epilepsy normally follows which of the following sequences
options: Aura, tonic phase, clonic phase, recovery
Aura, clonic phase, tonic phase, recovery
questions.explanation: Involve patient in setting realistic goals to increase adherence.

questions.question: Mr Jones aged 72 years has chronic obstructive respiratory disease (CORD). He is a smoker. In the early stages of CORD the most effective way of delaying the disease process is to encourage Mr. Jones to
options: Use purse lip breathing and pace physical activity
questions.explanation: Behavioural goals must be specific and measurable.

questions.question: The safest and most effective way to clear secretions from the respiratory tract is
questions.explanation: Generalisation requires practice across settings and cues.

questions.question: Carl comes to the mental health clinic where you work because of nervousness. He tells you I have butterflies in my stomach most of the time. I haven‟t missed work but it is getting harder to concentrate on things for a long time. What level of anxiety is Carl most likely experiencing
questions.explanation: Confabulation typical in dementia; sundowning common.

questions.question: Which of the following questions would be the best way to begin taking carls history
options: Could you tell me about your family
Have you ever felt this way before
Does anyone else in your family experience these feelings
questions.explanation: Wandering risk: ensure safety—ID bracelet, secure environment.

questions.question: Which of the following explains the major differences between normal anxiety and the syndrome associated with anxiety reactions Page 96 of 203
options: Normal anxiety is constant; an anxiety reaction is intermittent and rather short lived
Normal anxiety is free floating; in an anxiety reaction there is an impending sense of doom
An anxiety reaction is seldom controllable and usually must run its course
Normal anxiety is a fact of life and rarely becomes an anxiety reaction
questions.explanation: Validate feelings and reorient gently in Alzheimer’s.

questions.question: Signs and symptoms associated with anxiety are
options: Complaints of apprehension, narrowed perception, stomach pains and restlessness
Inability to get to sleep, early morning awakening, excessive weight loss and lack of energy
Ideas of reference, grandiose delusion, hallucinations and delusions
Spending or giving away large amounts of money
questions.explanation: Primary prevention: promote mental health and stress management.

questions.question: Carl complains of severe inner left arm and neck pain during the last few days. This pain probably the result of
options: Irritation of nerve endings in the cardiac plexus
questions.explanation: Alcohol withdrawal: tremor, agitation, sweating early.

questions.question: Carl collapses in a shopping mall as he experiences a cardiac arrest. What would be the first action in this situation
options: Give a bolus of sodium bicarbonate
questions.explanation: Delirium tremens hallmarks: confusion, hallucinations, autonomic instability.

questions.question: Upon admission to the coronary care unit, oxygen was ordered for Carl. The primary purpose of oxygen administration in this situation is to
options: Increase oxygen concentration in the myocardium
questions.explanation: Cardiac rehab: resume sexual activity when can climb two flights of stairs without symptoms (~4–6 weeks).

questions.question: The most dangerous period for Carl, following his myocardial infarction is
options: 4 to 10 days after the myocardial infarction
From the onset of symptoms until treatment begins
questions.explanation: Dressings change timing: complications (rupture) usually 3–7 days post-MI; but pericarditis may occur 2–4 days—best '4–10 days' for rupture risk.

questions.question: Carl is now considerably improved, wants to talk about his sexual activity after he has been discharged. What would be the nurses initial approach
options: Give Carl some written material and then answer questions
Plan a teaching session with Carl and his wife
Answer his questions accurately and directly
Provide enough time and privacy so that he can express his concerns fully
questions.explanation: First allow expression of concerns fully (therapeutic communication).

questions.question: Michael has been brought by the police into the psychiatric unit. He was found curled up under a bridge. When asked his name all he would say was nice boy. His father Page 97 of 203 informs you that he has not had a psychotic episode for 2 years, and that medication has controlled his condition. This episode occurred when Michael refused his medication. Which of the following areas should the nurse gather data first
options: The observations of Michael, made by the police
questions.explanation: First assess physical condition to ensure safety (vitals, injuries).

questions.question: Michael becomes regressed and withdrawn. He appears to be listening to something, the nurse hears nothing. What is the most appropriate response
options: Give him an additional dose of his antipsychotic medication
Contact his doctor and request a seclusion order
Talk to him about what he has experiencing
questions.explanation: Explore what he is experiencing; talk about content/feelings.

questions.question: Michael‟s doctor prescribes haloperidol, 6mgs IM for three doses. After the third dose of the medication, Michael is still severely regressed and also agitated. He also appears to be hallucinating. What would the nurse do
options: Call the doctor for further orders
Administer another dose of the medication
Record the results of the medication
Observe the client for an hour
questions.explanation: Dystonic reaction? If still agitated with hallucinations after Haldol IM, call doctor for further orders.

questions.question: Michael yells for the nurse. As the nurse enters his room he says do you see there the Virgin Mary is appearing. Which of the following is the best nursing response
options: No I don‟t see her but I understand she is real to you
She is not there. You must be imagining things Michael
Show me where in the room she is appearing
questions.explanation: Acknowledge experience without validating hallucination.

questions.question: Michael is very withdrawn, he moves slowly and is uncommunicative. The best initial goal is which of the following
options: Michael will increase his social skills
Michael will be orientated to reality
Michael will increase his level of communication
Michael will form a trusting relationship with the nurse
questions.explanation: Paranoid delusions: maintain distance and avoid whispering; use clear, direct communication.

questions.question: Jeff Oakes has cancer of the rectum and has consented to surgery for removal of the rectum and the formation of a permanent colostomy. A gastric suction tube is inserted before Mr. Oakes goes to surgery in order to
options: Facilitate administration of high caloric, nutritious liquids immediately after completion of the procedure
Prevent accumulation of gas and fluid in the stomach both during and following surgical action
Provide a reliable means of detecting gastrointestinal haemorrhage during the operative procedure
Serve as a stimulus to restore normal peristaltic movement following recovery from anaesthesia
questions.explanation: When offering help, be concrete and brief; avoid excessive stimulation.

questions.question: Sections of colon both above and below the tumour were removed in order to prevent
options: Direct extension and metastatic spread of the tumour Page 98 of 203
Post op paralysis and distension of the bowel
Accidental loosening of bowel sutures post operatively
Pressure injury to perineal suture line
questions.explanation: Give IM depot if severe noncompliance and acute agitation per order.

questions.question: Mr Oakes will receive tube feedings post operatively. Tube feedings provide adequate nutrition for all of the following clients except
options: Those who have difficulty in swallowing
Those who do not have a functioning gastrointestinal tract
questions.explanation: Dissociative disorder features disturbances in memory/identity.

questions.question: Mr Oakes recovers from surgery. He is scheduled to return to the hospital in a month for a course of chemotherapy. Before leaving he says to you I‟m not sure I want to come back. Maybe I‟ll just take my chances. What would be the best response
options: It is your decision and you should do as you feel best
What concerns you most about coming back
Have you discussed this with your wife and doctor
The survival rate with adjuvant chemotherapy is quite high
questions.explanation: Seizure precautions include side rails up, padding, suction ready.

questions.question: Four year old Sean white was admitted to hospital with burns received while playing with matches. His legs and lower abdomen are burned. On assessment of Sean's hydration status, which of the following indicates less than adequate fluid replacement
options: Decreasing hematocrit and increasing urine volume
Falling hematocrit and decreasing urine volume
Rising hematocrit and decreasing urine volume
Stable hematocrit and increasing urine volume
questions.explanation: Report abuse if suspected; confidentiality does not override safety.

questions.question: Which signs/symptoms indicate overhydration
options: Warmth and redness around intravenous site
questions.explanation: Do not leave suicidal patient alone; maintain observation and safety.

questions.question: Sean‟s output via his foley catheter is 10mL/hour. What should be the first nursing action
options: Check the catheter to see if it is plugged (blocked)
Record the information on the chart
questions.explanation: Non-judgmental support for postpartum depression includes encouraging expression of feelings.

questions.question: The doctor has prescribed 500ml of IV fluid to be given over 10 hours. Using a soluset which delivers 60 drops per ml, calculate the rate in drops per min
questions.explanation: Peptic ulcer risk factors include NSAIDs, H. pylori, smoking, stress.

questions.question: Sean starts oral feeding it is particularly important that his client has a high amount of
questions.explanation: Total hip replacement: avoid flexion >90° to prevent dislocation.

questions.question: What would be the best diversional activity for Sean while he is in reverse isolation
questions.explanation: Do not put a pillow under the knee post-op hip replacement due to VTE risk.

questions.question: Christine Harvey, aged 21 is to have a bronchoscopy in two hours time under general anaesthetic. Why are food or fluids not permitted before this procedure
options: The anaesthetic will not be absorbed
Vomiting may occur during the procedure
Indigestion may be a problem for Christine
questions.explanation: DVT prevention: early ambulation, ankle pumps, SCDs.

questions.question: Christine refuses to remove her wedding ring before she is transferred to theatre. Which action should you take in this situation
options: Remind her that you are not responsible for the loss
Warn her the ring may slip off during surgery
Tell he she should give the ring to her husband
Secure the ring to her finger with tape
questions.explanation: NPO pre-anaesthetic to reduce aspiration risk.

questions.question: Christine is asked to remove her make up before going to theatre. Why is this important
options: The makeup may contaminate the anaesthetic mask
The anaesthetist may have difficulty assessing her condition
The theatre is a sterile environment and make up carries micro organisms
The facemask is more likely to slip if she is wearing makeup
questions.explanation: Post-anaesthesia: monitor airway and breathing first.

questions.question: Soon after returning to the ward Christine asks for a drink. She should be given water first, rather than a milky drink
options: Water is more easily absorbed than milk
Water quenches a person‟s thirst more rapidly
Milk can cause lung infection if the gag reflex has not returned
Milk has a more irritating effect on a person‟s throat
questions.explanation: Do not give milk post-tonsillectomy—risk of vomiting and mucous.

questions.question: Allan martin, is admitted to hospital with acute chest pain. Provisional diagnosis is myocardial infarction. When asking about the quality of a clients chest pain you are primarily looking for
options: A response found on a list of possible descriptions
questions.explanation: Use patient’s own words to characterise pain quality.

questions.question: When a client is anxious and upset about chest pain, it is best to
options: Explain in detail the pathologic changes that may be occurring
Provide short, clear explanations of your assessment and treatment interventions
Don‟t say anything until you are sure of his diagnosis
Explain that his doctor can answer his questions better Page 100 of 203
questions.explanation: Short, clear explanations reduce anxiety during acute chest pain.

questions.question: The nurse asks you to check some pain relief for Mr. Martin‟s severe chest pain. This prescription is for morphine 6mgs every 2 hours. The stock available is morphine 10mg in 1 ml. calculate the correct amount
questions.explanation: 5 mg with 10 mg/mL → 0.5 mL.

questions.question: The doctor prescribes Frusemide (lasix) intravenously for Mr. Martin. What is the action of Frusemide
questions.explanation: Frusemide is a loop diuretic.

questions.question: What side effects of Frusemide (lasix) should the nurse be aware of
questions.explanation: Watch for hypovolaemia and hypotension (fluid loss).

questions.question: The doctor prescribes heparin 7,500 i.u subcutaneous BID. The vial contains heparin 25,000 units/ml. what volume should be given s.c
questions.explanation: Diuretics can cause hypokalaemia—monitor K⁺.

questions.question: What is the essential nursing action to take when caring for a patient who is having heparin
options: Watch for side effects of the drug
Record blood pressure and pulse 4 hourly
Monitor patient for signs of internal or external haemorrhage
questions.explanation: Bronchodilators relieve wheeze/dyspnoea in asthma/COPD.

questions.question: Mrs Phillips is admitted to your ward in acute respiratory distress following an asthmatic attack. In which position should the nurse place Mrs. Phillips to assist her breathing
questions.explanation: After cardiac arrest, pupils may dilate; check brainstem signs.

questions.question: Which signs would indicate your client may have hypoxaemia
options: Hyperventilation, warm peripheries, alert Page 101 of 203
questions.explanation: Sudden severe headache may suggest SAH; emergent eval.

questions.question: Mrs Phillips is prescribed 1 litre of normal saline .9% over 6 hours. This is to be delivered via a soluset which has a drop factor of 60. Calculate the correct drops per minute
questions.explanation: TBP: airborne precautions—N95, negative pressure.

questions.question: Mrs Maring was brought to an acute psychiatric unit by the police. She was found wandering around the streets, incoherent, and her behaviour appeared to be inappropriate. She was tentatively diagnosed as having schizophrenia. The nurse knows that a diagnosis of schizophrenia implies that a patient would manifest which of the following behaviours
questions.explanation: Rib fracture pain increases with deep breathing and movement.

questions.question: Mrs Maring says that the voices are telling her to do things and she can‟t stop listening. The best response from the nurse would be
options: Never mind the voices; let‟s just concentrate on the game
The voices will go away soon
I don‟t hear any voices. I think the voices are part of your illness. Try to listen to what I‟m saying
questions.explanation: Pneumothorax: hyperresonant sound on percussion.

questions.question: Mrs Maring after a two week stay, appears much better. She is in contact with reality and is able to interact with others in an appropriate way. The doctor is sending her home with medication. The most common medications given for schizophrenia are
questions.explanation: Haemothorax: dullness to percussion over affected side.

questions.question: A young Maori man dies, as a result of a motor bike accident. The doctor requests his kidneys for a transplant. His whanau refuse. What is the most appropriate action of the nurse in this situation
options: You accept the wishes of the whanau
You pressure the whanau to re consider
You seek permission from other whanau members
You support the doctor to over ride what the whanau wish to do
questions.explanation: Chest drain: bubbling in water seal indicates air leak.

questions.question: Mr H a 72 year old kaumatua (elder) is admitted to the medical ward with cellulitis of his left leg. He is placed on strict bed rest. Because he is whakama (embarrassed) he refuses to use a bedpan and demands to walk to the toilet. How should you deal with this situation
options: Give him a bed pan anyway
Talk over the situation with him
Tell him to doctor has ordered bed rest
Ask the other patients to leave the room Page 102 of 203
questions.explanation: Aspirin is contraindicated in children with viral illness (Reye's risk).

questions.question: While assessing Mr. h you find his daughter answers all your questions for him. The most culturally appropriate action is to
options: Question him privately when the daughter leaves
Send her out so Mr. h will answer on his own
Accept this as appropriate and continue the assessment
Ignore her as you need to have the information form Mr. H
questions.explanation: Acetaminophen overdose antidote is N-acetylcysteine.

questions.question: The tohunga (healer) prescribes a specially prepared solution to be placed on Mr. H legs. What is the most appropriate response in this situation
options: Get the doctor to talk to the tohunga
Refuse as it may be unhygienic and cause infection
Explain to Mr. h that medication from the doctor is more acceptable
Ensure both types of treatment may be combined to assist Mr. h
questions.explanation: Glucagon raises blood glucose in hypoglycaemia.

questions.question: Mr T aged 80 has had a right below knee amputation. As a Maori he wishes that his amputated foot be returned to him. What is the cultural significance of this request
options: It is the appropriate action to do in Maori society today
Maori people prefer to keep all their body parts after surgery
Because of the spiritual links between Maori people and the land
Because he is worried about what the hospital will do with his foot
questions.explanation: Insulin shock manifests with sweating, tremor, hunger, confusion.

questions.question: Following a cerebral vascular accident (stroke) Mr. M aged 80 is unconscious. Some members of the whanau (extended family) wish to take him home. What is the most appropriate action to take in this situation
options: Help and support the whanau appropriately
Tell them that Mr. h needs hospital care
Check to ensure they have enough whanau support
Ask if the whanau are capable of nursing him safely
questions.explanation: Foot care diabetic: inspect daily; proper footwear; avoid barefoot.

questions.question: A Maori manager 26 dies within 24 hours of admission in the A and E clinic in which you work. His family wish to take him home immediately to prepare for his tangi. He has not been certified dead by a doctor and because of his death within 24 hours, it becomes a coroner‟s case. Your response to the whanau is
options: Ask them under what circumstances he died
Ask them if they understood the process of certification and coroners proceedings
questions.explanation: OTC cold meds can contain decongestants unsafe with hypertension.

questions.question: True labour can be differentiated from prodromal or false labour in that in true labour there is a
options: Strengthening of uterine contractions with walking
Failure of presenting part to descend
Lack of cervical effacement or dilation
Cessation of uterine contractions with walking
questions.explanation: True labour contractions strengthen with activity and cause cervical change.

questions.question: First foetal movements felt by the mother are known as
questions.explanation: Quickening = first fetal movements felt.

questions.question: Growth is most rapid during the phase of prenatal development known as

questions.question: The chief function of progesterone is the
options: Establishing of secondary male sex characteristics
Rupturing of follicles for ovulation to occur
Preparation of the uterus to receive a fertilised ovum
questions.explanation: Progesterone prepares and maintains endometrium for implantation.

questions.question: Mrs Green a 22 year old primigravida is attending prenatal clinic. Mrs Green is concerned because she has read that nutrition during pregnancy is important for proper growth and development of the baby. She wants to know something about the foods she should eat. The nurse should
options: Give her a list of foods so she can better plan her meals
Assess what she eats by taking a diet history
Emphasise the importance of limiting salt and highly seasoned foods
Instruct her to continue eating a normal diet
questions.explanation: Assess current diet first via diet history before teaching.

Don‟t worry about gaining weight. We are more concerned if you don‟t gain enough weight to ensure proper growth of your baby
The pattern of your weight gain will be of more importance than the total amount
If you gain over 7 kgs you‟ll have to follow a low calorie diet

questions.question: Which part of the hands is most affected in cases of primary irritant dermatitis

questions.question: Why is this particular area of the hands most affected

questions.question: Lucy is charted 5mls of augmentin 125 TDS. You notice the doctor hasn‟t signed the order form. A senior colleague tells you to give it. You respond by
options: Contacting the doctor to sign the order
Asking Lucy if the doctor told her she would have this
Signing the form for the doctor
questions.explanation: Primary prevention immunisations protect against specific infections.

questions.question: The augmentin is given to Lucy. She is found to be allergic when she exhibits
questions.explanation: Acute glomerulonephritis often follows streptococcal infection.

questions.question: Jack is 15 years old. He is admitted to the hospital after briefly losing consciousness when tackled during a rugby game. Which of the following is an indication increasing intracranial pressure
options: Change in his level of consciousness
Blurred vision and halos around lights
questions.explanation: Minimal change disease causes nephrotic syndrome in children.

questions.question: Jack has had two seizures while hospitalised. These have been controlled by anticonvulsant medications. Jack and his family must understand
options: The medication must be taken for at least one year
The doctor should be seen when the prescription has finished
The medication will be discontinued on discharge
The medication will be necessary for the rest of his life
questions.explanation: UTI commonly due to E. coli ascending from perineum.

questions.question: Jack is prescribed rivotril 8 mgs daily. He weighs 68 kgs. The initial doses for 2-3 days should not exceed 0.01 mgs/kg/day. Your nursing responsibility is to
options: Observe for any side effects after giving the drug
Contact the doctor to reassess the dose prescribed
Consider his weight loss and administer the dose prescribed
Check with the charge nurse prior to administration Page 105 of 203
questions.explanation: Pyelonephritis: costovertebral angle tenderness and fever.

questions.question: Lucy Rogers, 5 years old, has had a recent upper respiratory tract infection. Now she is febrile and complains of a painful left ear. Acute otitis media is diagnosed. The typical appearance of the tympanic membrane in acute otitis media is
questions.explanation: Nephrotic syndrome hallmark is proteinuria with oedema.

questions.question: Lucy‟s symptoms may be relieved most effectively by
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A spreads fecal–oral; ensure hygiene and safe food.

questions.question: Children are more likely to develop acute otitis media from an upper respiratory infection than adults because of their
options: Lack of acquired immunity to the causative organism
questions.explanation: Diphtheria produces a pseudomembrane and is prevented by immunisation.

questions.question: The organism most commonly responsible for acute otitis media is
questions.explanation: Hib vaccine prevents Haemophilus influenzae type B infections.

questions.question: Kevin aged 19 is admitted with an acute attack of asthma. During an asthmatic attack, the reaction to excessive histamine release would be 1. Bronchospasm 2. Bronchodilation 3. Excessive mucous production 4. Production of I.G.E antibodies
questions.explanation: Bronchoconstriction and mucus hypersecretion; select 1,3,5? Original items unclear; best: 1,3,5.

questions.question: The hypersensitive reaction in asthma is due to the

questions.question: Which of the following signs would a person admitted to hospital with an acute attack of asthma present with
options: Increased anxiety, sweating, chest pain Page 106 of 203
questions.explanation: Acute asthma: dyspnoea, tachycardia, anxiety common.

questions.question: A primiparous woman, one day postpartum, calls the nurse into her room the woman explains that while breastfeeding, she experienced uterine cramps and a heavy gush that soaked through her pad to the bed. The nurse should
options: Tell the woman that this often happens when breastfeeding
Assist the woman with perineal care and changing her pad
questions.explanation: Heavy gush postpartum: first assess fundus for atony.

questions.question: The lochia of the postpartum woman second day after birth should exhibit each of the following except
options: Moderate amount – 15cm on pad after 1 hour
questions.explanation: Large clots are not expected—could indicate atony or retained tissue.

questions.question: The risk for constipation in the postpartum period is related to all except
options: Fear of pain and of ripping sutures during a bowel movement
questions.explanation: Neonatal respiratory distress shows nasal flaring and grunting.

questions.question: Primary sites for postpartum infections would include all of the following except
questions.explanation: Hypoglycaemia in newborn: jitteriness, hypotonia, temperature instability.

questions.question: When caring for a postpartum woman with a uterine infection the nurse should
options: Administer an antipyretic when the temperature rises above 37.5oC
Provide at least 2000mls of fluid a day
Obtain specimens for cultures before initiating antibiotic treatment
Reassure the woman that future reproduction will not be affected
questions.explanation: Preeclampsia severe feature: hyperreflexia with clonus, headache, visual changes.

questions.question: A definition of cor pulmonale is
options: L) sided heart failure secondary to disease of the lungs
L) sided heart failure secondary to R) sided heart failure
R) sided heart failure secondary to severe lung disease
Disease of the lungs secondary to R) sided heart failure
questions.explanation: Magnesium sulfate prevents seizures in severe preeclampsia.

questions.question: The main function of alveoli is

questions.question: The patency of the trachea is maintained by
questions.explanation: Breastfeeding benefits: decreased otitis media, GI infections, bonding.

questions.question: Human milk is preferably to cow‟s milk because
options: Human milk is a non laxative effect
Human milk has more calories per ml
Human milk is great mineral content
Human milk offers greater immunologic benefits
questions.explanation: Formula feeding lacks antibodies and may increase infection risk.

questions.question: Which of the following neonates will most likely need additional respiratory support at birth
options: The infant born by normal vaginal delivery
The infant born by caesarean birth
The infant born vaginally after 12 hours of labour
The infant born with high levels of surfactant
questions.explanation: Neonatal jaundice monitoring: observe sclera/skin and measure bilirubin.

questions.question: During the transition from foetal to neonatal circulation, the newborn cardiovascular system accomplishes which of the following anatomic and physiologic alterations 1. Closure of the ductus venosus 2. Closure of the foramen ovale 3. Closure of the ductus arteriosis 4. Increased systemic pressure and decreased pulmonary artery pressure
questions.explanation: Physiologic jaundice appears after 24 hours; pathologic within 24h.

questions.question: A woman diagnosed with marginal placenta praevia gave birth vaginally 15 minutes ago. She is at greatest risk for
questions.explanation: Phototherapy: protect eyes, maintain hydration, monitor temperature.

questions.question: The primary nursing focus of the fourth stage of labour would be to
questions.explanation: Breast milk jaundice develops after first week; continue breastfeeding.

questions.question: Which of the following results of emphysema is primarily responsible for cardiomegaly
options: Hypertrophy of muscles encircling the bronchi
Increased pressure in the pulmonary circulation
Decreased number of circulating red blood cells
Secretion of excessive amounts of pericardial fluids
questions.explanation: Meconium aspiration risk with fetal distress; suction airway at birth if needed.

questions.question: The tissue change most characteristic of emphysema is
options: Accumulation of pus in the pleural space
Constriction of capillaries by fibrous tissue
Filling of air passages by inflammatory coagulum Page 108 of 203
Over-distention, inelasticity and rupture of alveoli

questions.question: Which of the following positions is most comfortable for a person with emphysema
options: Sitting of the edge of the bed
questions.explanation: Preterm complications: RDS, NEC, IVH.

questions.question: A person of the following factors commonly predisposes to emphysematous lung changes
options: Chemical irritation of bronchiolar and alveolar linings
Sudden increase in intrapulmonary pressure coincident with hypertension
Obstruction of air passages by spasms of bronchiolar muscles
Senile degenerative changes in the vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs
questions.explanation: COPD hallmark: chronic airflow limitation from airway inflammation.

questions.question: Oxygen therapy is administered at low concentrations (below 35%), for people with chronically elevated pCO2 levels, as for some people with chronic obstructive respiratory disease, in order to prevent
options: Decrease in red blood cell formation
questions.explanation: Low-flow oxygen to avoid depressing hypoxic drive.

questions.question: A newborns birth weight is 3400krms. The maximum expected weight loss for this newborn would be
questions.explanation: Max expected loss ≈ 10% → 340 g from 3.4 kg.

questions.question: The birth weight of a breast feed newborn was 3600 grms. On the third day the newborns weight was 3350 grms. The nurse should
options: Encourage the mother to continue breast feeding as her baby‟s nutrient and fluid needs are being met
Suggest that the mother switch to bottle feeding as breastfeeding is ineffective in meeting her baby‟s needs
Notify the doctor as the baby has lost too much weight
Refer the mother to a lactation consultant to improve her breastfeeding technique
questions.explanation: 6.9% loss on day 3 is within expected; encourage breastfeeding.

questions.question: Which of the following would be an unexpected sign of dehydration in the newborn
options: Decreased frequency and amount of urine
questions.explanation: Decreased frequency/amount of urine is unexpected sign.

questions.question: The nurse would recognise that a new mother understood breastfeeding instructions when she explains
options: I feed my baby every two hours around the clock
I always start feeding on my right breast, as my baby feeds best on that breast
I use both the football and the traditional positions for feeding Page 109 of 203
I let my baby continue to suck for a while on the second breast once its empty
questions.explanation: Using multiple positions is fine; feed on demand generally 2–3 hourly initially.

questions.question: Which of the following actions of a breastfeeding mother indicate the need for further instruction
options: Holds breast with four fingers along the bottom and thumb at the top
Leans forward to bring breast towards the baby
Stimulates the rooting reflex than inserts nipple and areola into newborns open mouth
Puts her finger into newborns mouth before removing breast
questions.explanation: Mastitis: frequent emptying, antibiotics if infected, continue breastfeeding if not abscessed.

questions.question: Characteristically, respirations of the client in diabetic acidosis are
questions.explanation: Breast engorgement: warm compress before feeding, cold after.

questions.question: The most important feature of foot care for a diabetic would be to

questions.question: Excessive thirst for people with diabetes mellitus is a result of
options: Need for increased amounts of water to hydrolyse food during digestion
Loss of excessive body water due to increased daily urine volume
Reflex adaption to a sustained elevation of body temperature
Compensatory adjustment to decreased production of posterior pituitary hormone
questions.explanation: Postpartum: fundus firm at umbilicus then descends 1 cm/day.

questions.question: For people with diabetes mellitus polyuria is the result of
options: Increased glomerular permeability due to generalized vascular damage
Increased glomerular filtration due to decreased serum albumin concentration
Increased volume of glomerular filtrate due to elevated blood pressure
Decreased water resorption due to high tubular osmotic pressure
questions.explanation: Postpartum infection signs include fever and malodorous lochia.

questions.question: A normal CBG (capillary blood glucose) reading is within the range of
questions.explanation: Postpartum haemorrhage: massage fundus, call for help, medications.

questions.question: The foetal presenting part is described as vertex when the
options: Buttocks emerge with legs extended over the abdomen
questions.explanation: Postpartum blues common in first week; resolve spontaneously.

questions.question: When examining the umbilical cord immediately after birth the nurse should expect to observe
questions.explanation: Postpartum depression requires assessment and possible therapy.

questions.question: Vitamin K is given to the newborn to
options: Increase the production of red blood cells
Enhance the ability of the blood to clot
questions.explanation: Postpartum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency.

questions.question: The nurse is performing a 5 minute apgar on a newborn. Which of the following observations is included in the apgar score
questions.explanation: Rh incompatibility: anti-D immunoglobulin after delivery if baby Rh+.

questions.question: At birth the major cause of heat loss is by
questions.explanation: Phototherapy contraindication: dehydration; ensure adequate hydration.

questions.question: The newborn would respond most effectively to feeding in which state
questions.explanation: Exclusive breastfeeding for first 6 months recommended.

questions.question: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks gestation exhibits a rise in her baseline systolic blood pressure of 32mmHg, a weight gain of 4 kgs since last week and difficulty removing rings she normally wears. This is suggestive of
questions.explanation: Introduce solids around 6 months, starting with iron-fortified cereal.

questions.question: The primary pathophysiologic basis for the clinical manifestations of pregnancy induced hypertension (PIH) is
options: Fluid retention related to excessive salt intake
Ineffective excretion of fluid by the kidneys
Ineffective dilatation of the vascular network to accommodate the expanding blood volume of pregnancy
questions.explanation: Weaning gradually reduces engorgement and maintains comfort.

questions.question: Which measure would be least effective in relieving the signs and symptoms of mild pre eclampsia
options: Balanced diet with protein Page 111 of 203
questions.explanation: Teen pregnancy risks include preterm birth and low birth weight; provide support.

questions.question: A woman with severe pre eclampsia is being monitored for assessment findings indicative of cerebral oedema and venospasm. Which of the following would you not expect to find
options: Vision changes including blurring and spots before the eyes
questions.explanation: Severe preeclampsia shows hyperreflexia, not hypotonic reflexes.

questions.question: Newly expectant parents, ask the nurse how they can prepare their 3yr old preschool daughter for the new baby. All of the following would be useful except
options: Tell the child about the pregnancy as soon as mother begins to look pregnant
Arrange for a few sleep overs with the person who will care for the child at the time of the birth
Transfer their child to her new room and bed just before the expected birth of the baby
Introduce their child to preschool as soon as possible
questions.explanation: Avoid major changes (like new bed/room) right before birth to reduce stress.

questions.question: A patient with a diagnosis of schizophrenia says to the nurse „I‟m like a fallen star. But I won‟t go to the bar… it would be mar on my family, on the tar‟. This is an example of
questions.explanation: Rhyming based associations indicate clang association.

questions.question: A person diagnosed with schizophrenia tells the nurse that „the voices have told me I‟m in danger‟. He stays in his room, wears the same clothes, and avoids cracks on the floor. The nurses best initial response to this information is
options: I know that these voices are real to you, but I don‟t hear them
Don‟t worry, you‟re safe here. I won‟t let anything happen to you
You need to get out of your room and get your mind occupied
Would you like some p.r.n medication
questions.explanation: Validate perception without agreeing, and orient to reality.

questions.question: Mr P a new client on the ward, allows himself to be escorted to the day room. However he does not speak in response to you. The most therapeutic nursing intervention is to
options: Ignore his silence and talk about superficial topics such as the weather
Involve him in group psychotherapy so other patients can encourage him to talk
Point out that he is making others uncomfortable with his silences
Plan time to spend with him, in silence, if that is his choice
questions.explanation: Begin with simple, nonthreatening engagement and allow silence.

questions.question: In communicating with a client experiencing delusions, what is it best to do
options: Tell the client that they aren‟t real
Acknowledge his belief, but state your own understanding
Ignore this topic when it is brought up
questions.explanation: Therapeutic milieu emphasises safety, structure, support.

questions.question: Mr P is prescribed Clozapine tablets, initially at 50mg mane and 100 mg nocte. What is the most likely side effect that will be first noted Page 112 of 203
questions.explanation: Agoraphobia = fear of open/public places.

questions.question: On discharge what is the most important piece of information you must give to Mr. p
options: Report any flu like symptoms immediately
Ensure no doses of clozapine are missed
questions.explanation: Acute mania: set limits, reduce stimulation, short directions.

questions.question: Which of the following represents a positive change of pregnancy
options: Foetal heart beat auscultated with Doppler
questions.explanation: Antidepressants may cause anticholinergic effects.

questions.question: Which of the following statements can be used as a guideline for planning diets during pregnancy
options: A increase of 300 calories per day beginning in the first trimester
A ten percent increase in protein above daily requirements
Iron supplementation is recommended for women whose diets are lacking in iron
The requirement for folic acid is increased by 50 percent
questions.explanation: ECT is indicated for severe depression with psychotic features/when meds fail.

questions.question: In order to percent infection of hepatitis B virus, the pregnant woman should
options: Receive gamma globulin during the first trimester
Carefully wash hands before eating or preparing food
Take AZT during the second and third trimester
questions.explanation: SSRIs commonly cause sexual dysfunction.

questions.question: Which of the following represents a recommended weight gain during pregnancy
questions.explanation: Lithium requires serum level monitoring.

questions.question: John‟s behaviour are increasingly annoying to other patients. The best nursing approach is to
options: Explain that he must try to conserve his energy
Set limits on his behaviours and be consistent in approach
Tell him he is annoying to others and ask him to stay in his room
Ask him to walk to town to burn off energy
questions.explanation: Hypomania: elevated mood without marked impairment.

questions.question: John also has been described as having flight of ideas. These would be likely present when john
options: Asks for a cup of tea, but tells you later he doesn‟t want it
Takes a long time to make his point in conversation
Rapidly changes topic in conversation, sometimes without apparent connection
Speaks in a staccato voice and says words you don‟t understand Page 113 of 203
questions.explanation: Provide high-calorie finger foods due to hyperactivity.

questions.question: John has been prescribed chlorpromazine (largactil) tablets 150mg nocte since being on the ward. The most likely reason for this is to
options: To reduce agitation, anxiety and tension
To prevent long term mood swings
questions.explanation: Avoid competitive games; choose solitary, calming activities.

questions.question: John tells you he feels faint when he first gets out of bed, since taking the largactil. Which response would best assist john
options: Tell him not to get until the nurse is present
Suggest he does not get up until he has taken the medication
Tell him to discuss this with the doctor
Explain he should sit on the bed for a time before standing
questions.explanation: Give brief, simple, concrete directions.

questions.question: John has also taking lithium carbonate capsules. Creatinine clearance tests ordered during lithium carbonate therapy determines the functioning of the
questions.explanation: Anhedonia = inability to feel pleasure.

questions.question: Mihi means traditional greetings and is normally extended to 1. The land 2. The meeting house 3. The dead 4. The people present 5. The reason for the hui
questions.explanation: Somatic delusions involve bodily function.

questions.question: The internal migration of Maori people from rural to urban life since the mid 1940s has adversely affected Maori health. What is the most likely reason for this
options: Dietary changes from naturally produced to processed food
