Loss of cultural, social, and spiritual ties
questions.explanation: Acute psychosis: hallucinations, delusions, disorganised thought.

questions.question: Maori communities are encouraging Maori to be involved in health research with their own people. What is the most likely reason for this
options: That ownership of the information will remain with Maori
Previously there has been little feedback which has been useful to Maori
Non Maori promote themselves on Maori research
Non Maori researchers are unaware of Maori values Page 114 of 203
questions.explanation: Kaupapa Māori research: Māori control/benefit; non‑Māori unaware—answer best reflects empowerment? (best effort).

questions.question: Which of the following interventions would be most helpful for David in dealing with his impending death
options: Distract him by initiating conversation that does not deal with his disease
Encourage him to reach out and spend more time with his wife and children
Listen and encourage David to reminisce about his life
Help him to spend much of his time sleeping
questions.explanation: Life review and reminiscence is therapeutic near end of life.

questions.question: David tells the nurse, that he does not want his wife and children to know that his is dying. What would be the most helpful response
options: They would not want you to upset yourself by worrying about them
You are concerned that they will be distressed
I think we should talk about something less stressful for you
questions.explanation: Reflect concern about family’s distress to invite discussion.

questions.question: Which of the following interventions is the most effective in helping David‟s wife and children deal with David‟s impending death
options: Try to keep all the family at the same stage in the grieving process
Encourage the family to verbalise their grief to the nurse
Encourage the family to spend as much time as possible with David
Encourage the family to cry but not in the presence of David
questions.explanation: Time with the dying supports connection and anticipatory grief.

questions.question: Your client has cancer, nobody can tell him until his surgeon arrives from 5 days away. However in the meantime his anxiety is increasing. What should you do
options: Contact a social worker/chaplain to spend time with him
Give him relaxation tapes to listen to
Tell him his results are not back yet
Speak with the doctor who is acting in the surgeons place
questions.explanation: Communicate with covering doctor about rising anxiety/results.

questions.question: Your patient, who is a voluntary admission to a mental health unit, leaves the following day without telling anyone. Legally, what is required to staff
options: Provide care for him at home
Re admit him under a compulsory order
Get police to bring him in to sign a statement
Do nothing, the patient has rights to leave health care at any time
questions.explanation: Voluntary patient leaving: if unsafe, consider compulsory readmission (per local law).

questions.question: Pepe a 26 year old, developmentally delayed Maori man, who at aged two years contracted meningitis. He has been cared for in an institution, and is now to be moved to the community. Pepe is able to live in the community. What action should be taken now
options: Ring his whanau to advise them of his discharge
Ask the social worker to tell the family Pepe is to be discharged
Arrange for Pepe to visit with his whanau
Organise a conference with the whanau
questions.explanation: Pernicious anaemia due to intrinsic factor deficiency; B12 therapy is lifelong.

questions.question: What statement would best describe your next action
options: Organise regular meetings between nursing staff and whanau prior to discharge
Support Pepe's whanau in being able to visit and to be involved in his discharge planning
Invite the whanau in to explain what will be required of them in caring for Pepe
Make sure the whanau understand Pepe limitations in self care Page 115 of 203
questions.explanation: Cyanocobalamin IM monthly is typical maintenance.

questions.question: Pepe has been discharged to a marae based community house. How would you ensure his continued well being
options: Set up regular appointments to monitor Pepe‟s well being
Explain to the community workers Pepe‟s requirements
Arrange for Pepe to attend the local sheltered workshop
Ensure Pepe and his whanau have ongoing support and access to resources
questions.explanation: Folic acid corrects megaloblastosis but not neuro deficits—B12 needed.

questions.question: Blake a 65 year old kaumatua (elder) is admitted with urinary retention. He is quiet and appears withdrawn. Blake‟s whanau arrived. A female doctor tells them he needs a urinary catheter inserted. Blake‟s son refuses to have a young woman doctor catheterise his father. What is your most appropriate response
options: Let us talk about this together
I will contact the Maori support person for you
I will inform the doctor of your decision
Tell him that this is the only doctor available
questions.explanation: Subacute combined degeneration = neurological signs (paresthesias, ataxia).

questions.question: Blake falls in the shower sustaining a laceration to his right elbow. His family are angry and upset. What is the most appropriate action to take in this situation
options: Enquire of the whanau if Blake has had previous falls
Offer for them to take to the doctor
Acknowledge their anger and discuss ways to prevent further falls
Acknowledge their anger and ensure the whanau it will not happen again
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency anaemia from chronic blood loss.

questions.question: Charlie a 62 year old who identifies as Maori is admitted to your ward with shortness of breath. He is very anxious and has no family with him. What is the most appropriate initial action to take
options: Introduce Charlie to others in the room
Telephone his whanau to come and visit
Carry out a physical assessment on Charlie
Acknowledge Charlie‟s anxiety and ask how you can help
questions.explanation: Glucose intolerance test at 24–28 weeks (typical screening).

questions.question: Iris condition deteriorates and she dies. What is the most appropriate nursing action to help the whanau
options: Ensure privacy for the family to have karakia (prayers)
Allow a spokesperson to contact the rest of the family
Move iris body to a side room
Offer the whanau to go to a quiet room for a cup of tea
questions.explanation: Fetal movement („quickening‟) occurs ~16–20 weeks.

questions.question: The doctor asks the whanau for the corneas of iris for transplantation. The whanau cannot make a decision right now. What is the most appropriate action you should take in support of the whanau
options: Tell the doctor that this is not culturally appropriate
Listen to them and support them in their decision
Explain to the whanau why corneas are transplanted
Suggest the whanau talk to the hospital chaplain
questions.explanation: Rheumatic fever follows streptococcal infection.

questions.question: Stanley progresses well. His chest tube is removed. He still does not have much of an appetite and is concerned about his diet. Which of these responses would be of help
options: Eat three large meals a day that are high in carbohydrates
Eat three large meals a day that are high in protein Page 116 of 203
Eat six small meals a day that are high in carbohydrates
Eat six small meals a day that are high in protein
questions.explanation: Penicillin is used to treat strep throat to prevent RF.

questions.question: Select the most appropriate nursing intervention to assist. Stanley to mobilise without becoming breathless 1. Gradually increase mobility 2. Assess respiratory function related to mobility 3. Administer oxygen prior to mobilising 4. Increase time up by 10 minutes per day 5. Continually assess respiratory function
questions.explanation: Acute rheumatic fever presents with migratory polyarthritis, carditis, chorea.

questions.question: Tom a 38 year old businessman, voluntarily admits himself to a detoxification unit. He admits to drinking one large bottle of vodka each day. Which of the following ego defence mechanisms is a top and continuing priory in dealing with alcoholic clients
questions.explanation: Prophylaxis with penicillin prevents recurrences.

questions.question: Of the following approaches to the treatment of alcoholism, which has been found to be the most effective to date
options: Treatment alcoholism as a chronic disease
questions.explanation: Mitral valve damage common in rheumatic heart disease.

questions.question: Mr quang duc pho 65 years old is admitted to hospital after arriving with a group of boat people from Vietnam. On the basis of the results of a Mantou‟s test, chest x ray examination, and sputum cultures a diagnosis of active pulmonary tuberculosis is made. The most appropriate area in which to nurse Mr. quang on admission is
options: A single room, isolated from all other patients
Among other patients with infectious disease
questions.explanation: Patient in shock: ABCs—airway first.

questions.question: The nurse evaluates Mr. quangs Mantoux test as positive by the presence of
options: A small red swelling less than 7mm in diameter
Swelling and erythema together measuring between 7mm and 9mm
A lump greater than 7mm in diameter
questions.explanation: TST interpretation is based on the diameter of induration (a palpable lump), not erythema. Thresholds vary by risk; options here use 7 mm—choose the induration option.

questions.question: On Mr. quangs chest x ray film a lesion is observed in an upper lobe. Why is this area of the lung most commonly affected in tuberculosis
options: There is an slightly higher oxygen concentration in the upper lobes Page 117 of 203
Sputum collects more readily in upper lobes than in lower lobes
Upper lobes are less easily ventilated than are lower lobes
Tubercule bacilli are less dense than air and therefore remain in the upper lobes
questions.explanation: TB bacilli settle in upper lobes—aerobic organisms.

questions.question: Which of the following precautions must the nurse take when attending routinely to Mr. quang
options: Put on a gown, mask and gloves
Wash hands thoroughly after handling contaminated articles
Wear a mask when in close proximity to him
Insist that he wear a mask when care is given
questions.explanation: Standard: careful hand hygiene and appropriate masks; routine care at least hand hygiene.

questions.question: Mr quang tuberculosis is considered to be under control when
options: His chest x ray film is free of any lesion
He has three consecutive negative sputum cultures
His symptoms of tuberculosis have subsided
questions.explanation: Three consecutive negative sputum cultures indicate noninfectious.

questions.question: Quangs chemotherapy regime includes the drugs ethambutol, riampicin. What is the rationale for prescribing triple therapy for Mr. quang
options: The combination of three drugs is necessary to destroy the tubercule bacillus
If there is resistance to one drug, effective double therapy is assured
High serum levels of the drugs are achieved early in the treatment
The Asian strain of tuberculosis is particularly resistant the chemotherapy
questions.explanation: Multiple drugs cover resistance—if one fails, others act.

questions.question: Mr quangs daily ethambutol dosage is based on 25mg per kg of body weight. Given that he weighs 48kg and ethambutol is dispensed in 400mg tables, how many tablets should the nurse administer
questions.explanation: 25 mg/kg × 40 kg = 1000 mg → 400 mg tablets = 2.5; closest 3? But options 2/3/4/5; 1000/400=2.5 → round up 3 tablets.

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms are associated with ethambutol toxicity
questions.explanation: Ethambutol toxicity causes optic neuritis—blurred vision, colour blindness.

questions.question: Mr quangs is concerned because his urine has changed to an orange red colour. The most appropriate response is
options: This is a usual side effect of one of your tablets
Ill test your urine to see if there is blood present
This is a desired effect of your treatment
The drug which is causing this will be discontinued
questions.explanation: Red urine suggests rifampicin—educate about harmless discolouration.

questions.question: The most likely reason streptomycin is not prescribed for Mr. quang is because
options: Streptomycin is no longer considered an effective antituberculosis drug
His age puts him at risk for developing eighth cranial nerve damage
The drug is extremely potent and should be reserved for resistant strains of tuberculosis Page 118 of 203
His low bodyweight could predispose him to loss of visual acuity
questions.explanation: Isoniazid causes peripheral neuropathy—give pyridoxine (vit B6).

questions.question: For how long will Mr. quang need treatment
questions.explanation: Noncompliance is major cause of TB treatment failure.

questions.question: One of Mr. quangs cousins in Mantoux negative. Evaluate this finding
questions.explanation: INH can be hepatotoxic—monitor LFTs.

questions.question: Given his negative Mantoux reaction what is the appropriate action for Mr. quangs cousin
questions.explanation: PSG shows TB improved when sputum negative and symptoms improve.

questions.question: On commencing night duty it is noted that the other staff member on duty smells strongly of alcohol and does not appear to be in a fit state to be on duty. What action should be taken
options: Report the incident to nursing council
Make some strong coffee for him/her to counteract the alcohol
Ignore the situation as the alcohol was not drunk when on duty
Report the incident, as soon as possible, to a senior nurse on duty
questions.explanation: Pregnancy test detects hCG.

questions.question: You are working on a ward where several staff members complain about carrying another nurses workload. As a colleague, you have professional responsibility to
options: Tell them to do their own work and not be concerned with others
Suggest they speak to the nurse concerned in order to negotiate the workload
Talk to the nurse and encourage her to try some other form of work
Tell them to sort it out between themselves without involving other people
questions.explanation: Amenorrhoea is presumptive sign of pregnancy; hCG positive is probable.

questions.question: The NZNA standards for nursing practice were developed to
options: Provide outcome criteria for the evaluation of nursing practice
Provide a framework for standardised nursing care
Promote the development of a theory for nursing
Define the scope of nursing practice
questions.explanation: Fundal height at 20 weeks at umbilicus.

questions.question: Mrs Fitzpatrick, a client in a ward opposite Chris, asks the nurse „what is wrong with that person opposite me‟? what should the nurse say
options: Oh nothing, she just wanted to talk about some problems she is having
I‟ll get the doctor to talk to you
I‟m sorry I cannot disclose that information Page 119 of 203
questions.explanation: Lightening occurs near term—fetus descends; urinary frequency returns.

questions.question: Chris says he wants to discharge herself and go home. Which of the following is the best nursing response
options: I will ask the doctor to talk with you
It would be very unsafe for you to leave hospital without proper medical treatment
Can we walk about what is worrying you
If that‟s what you have decided I will get a self discharge form
questions.explanation: Braxton Hicks contractions are irregular and painless.

questions.question: Larry and Mary smith had planned their first pregnancy for some time, but when it is confirmed, Mary feels conflicting emotions. She comes to the clinic for her first prenatal (antenatal) visit at ten weeks gestation. Mary shares her mixed feelings about the pregnancy with the midwife. The midwifes best response would be to
options: Encourage her to consider abortion counselling
Encourage her to seek support from Larry
Reassure her that when she feels the baby move, her mixed feelings will disappear completely
Reassure her that most women experience some mixed feelings in early pregnancy, even when their pregnancies are planned
questions.explanation: Placenta previa: painless bleeding.

questions.question: Marys last menstrual period was 11 April. Her EDD (expected date of delivery) would be
questions.explanation: Abruptio placentae: painful bleeding with uterine tenderness.

questions.question: During a subsequent visit, Mary states she has begun to feel foetal movement. Foetal movement is usually felt by the pregnant woman when the foetus is approximately
questions.explanation: Threatened abortion: bleeding without dilation.

questions.question: Tui k is 22 years old and has missed two of her regular menstrual periods. Her doctor confirms she is pregnant. This is her first pregnancy. Tui can expect to experience all the following signs in the early stages of her pregnancy except
questions.explanation: Abruption placenta = premature separation—pain + bleeding.

questions.question: During tuis sixth week of pregnancy she experienced a small episode of vaginal bleeding. You should suspect
questions.explanation: Best education begins with assessment of learning needs.

questions.question: Tui asks for advice on diet. Which of the following is the best approach
options: Give her a list of the five basic food groups and tell her to include them in her daily intake Page 120 of 203
Tell her to increase her caloric intake so she gains about 12 kg during the pregnancy
Take a diet history that includes socio economic status, previous nutritional status and food preferences
Take a diet history, analyse it and say what foods she must now omit
questions.explanation: Take full diet history including preferences and SES first.

questions.question: Tui and her partner hawea, attend antenatal classes together. One of the topics discussed are danger signs of pregnancy. Which of the following is normal and not a danger sign
options: Regular contractions occurring before the due date
A sudden change in foetal activity patterns
questions.explanation: Leucorrhoea is a normal change; others are danger signs.

questions.question: At 34 weeks gestation, Mary is hospitalised with severe HOP (hypertension, oedema, and proteinuria) syndrome. Which of the following represents an unusual finding for this condition
options: Large amount of protein in the urine
questions.explanation: Eclampsia = seizures; unusual prior to severe preeclampsia—convulsions indicate severe complication.

questions.question: Candice meeker is expecting her first baby. Candice is interested in having an independent midwife deliver her baby. The certified midwife is licensed to
options: Manage the care of women throughout the childbearing cycle
Manage the care of women only during the intrapartal period
Manage the care of women throughout the childbearing cycle under direct supervision of a GP
Contract with a GP to do their prenatal care
questions.explanation: Certified midwife manages care across the childbearing cycle.

questions.question: John is timing the frequency of candices contractions. This means he is timing
options: From the end of one contraction to the beginning of the next
From the beginning of one contraction to the beginning of the next
From the beginning of one contraction until it begins to go away
From the beginning of one contraction until it is completely over
questions.explanation: Frequency is from beginning of one contraction to beginning of next.

questions.question: Neil grant, six months old, is admitted to the children‟s ward with severe dehydration due to vomiting and diarrhoea, IV fluids are commenced. One of the dangers of IV therapy is overhydration. This could lead to
questions.explanation: Duration is from beginning of one contraction to its end.

questions.question: Neil‟s blood pressure is very low. You realise that a low blood pressure is expected because
options: He has been receiving IV therapy
His circulating blood volume is low Page 121 of 203
questions.explanation: Engagement occurs when presenting part reaches ischial spines (station 0).

questions.question: Patty ray 6 years old, is admitted to the children‟s ward with a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Postural drainage is ordered for patty. Postural drainage consists of
options: Retraining techniques, allowing patty to be more active
Chest percussion and positioning to drain and remove secretions from patty‟s lungs
Providing patty with exercises that will assist her to control breathing and prevent dyspnoea
questions.explanation: Station = relation of presenting part to ischial spines.

questions.question: The most important nursing intervention in giving daily care to patty is
options: Forcing her to eat because she is malnourished
Seeing she receives the appropriate dietary regime
Frequent skin care to remove excessive salt deposits from increased perspiration
Having her repress her feelings of anger
questions.explanation: True labour: regular contractions causing cervical change.

questions.question: Patty spends a lot of time in the play room. What does make believe play in hospital provide for a child
options: Ability to accept a parent substitute
opportunity to learn to know other children more quickly
opportunity to reject the reality of the hospital
questions.explanation: False labour: irregular, relieved by rest/warmth, no cervical change.

questions.question: you are teaching patty‟s parents how to care for her at home. Which of the following do you include
options: regular medication dosage according to urine testing
use cough suppressant only at bedtime
do postural drainage three times a day
questions.explanation: Show indicates mucus plug discharge with slight blood.

questions.question: while working in the children‟s ward, the staff nurse asks you the following questions relating to legal issues. How would you reply. When may a child be treated without parental consent
options: if they need a blood transfusion
in the absence of a parent or guardian
questions.explanation: At crowning, support perineum to prevent tears.

questions.question: under what circumstances must permission from the court be sought to treat a minor
options: when the parent or guardian refuses treatment
in the case of parental absence, abandonment or incompetence
when the minor is seriously injured
in the case of parental separation
questions.explanation: Third stage: placental separation signs (gush of blood, cord lengthening).

questions.question: you are working with the public health nurse in a rural area. A mother attends the children‟s clinic asking for information regarding an outbreak of chicken pox in the area. You advise
options: that the effects of chicken pox on the child are minimal and the child‟s schooling will not be affected
that an immunisation is available for chicken pox for all children at 18 months of age Page 122 of 203
that chicken pox is a notifiable disease and the child must be seen by a general practitioner if you suspect this condition
that chicken pox is a contagious viral disease which can be transmitted by direct contact with skin lesions
questions.explanation: Immediate newborn care: clear airway, dry, warmth, APGAR.

questions.question: later that morning, Joan smith phones to tell you that her 18 month old son, Jared, has been diagnosed with whooping cough. Joan asks you what she can do for Jared. You suggest
options: regular fluids and increased food intake
continue as normal and encourage activity
humidified air, regular fluids and rest
isolate from other adults and rest
questions.explanation: Umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.

questions.question: Matthew, is nursed at rest with the head of the bed elevated to 30 degrees as directed. The purpose of this is to
options: prevent Mathew developing skin abrasions from shifting and turning in the bed
prevent Mathew from developing complications such as a DVT and chest infection
assisting Mathew to see and have conversations with the other patients in his cubicle
assisting in reducing any cerebral oedema Mathew may have and improving venous drainage from his head
questions.explanation: Lochia changes rubra → serosa → alba.

questions.question: your assessment of Matthew shows a widening pulse pressure. The term pulse pressure refers to
options: the difference between a bounding and or thread pulse
the difference between a bounding and thread pulse rate
the difference between diastolic and systolic blood pressure
the difference between diastolic blood pressure and pulse rate
questions.explanation: Uterus should be firm and midline postpartum; massage if boggy.

questions.question: Jacksons fracture is immobilised by open reduction and internal fixation. A nurse, new to the orthopaedic area asks you to explain what is meant by open reduction and internal fixation. You reply
options: bringing both bone ends into alignment by surgical intervention and holding them in position with a metal plate and screws
bringing bone ends into alignment by external manipulation and holding them in position with a Steinman pin and traction
bringing bone ends into alignment by external manipulation and holding them in position by an external fixating device
bringing bone ends into alignment by surgical intervention and holding them in position by a tight back slab and firm bandage
questions.explanation: Breastfeeding increases oxytocin, aiding involution.

questions.question: you are on duty in the surgical ward of a small rural hospital when James dickey aged 30 is admitted with a crush injury to his right arm. On arrival James arm is wrapped in a blood soaked towel, but he hasn‟t received any other first aid. As you do your initial assessment you note James has extensive soft tissue damage which includes a 15cm laceration, a large haematoma and severe bruising. James becomes very agitated at the sight of the haematoma and asks you to explain it. You reply
options: it was caused by splintering of underlying bone at the time of injury
it was caused by muscle spasm occurring at the time of injury Page 123 of 203
it was caused by blood vessels bleeding into the soft tissue at the time of injury
it was caused by the tearing of subcutaneous tissue at the time of injury
questions.explanation: Umbilical care: keep clean and dry.

questions.question: while treating James wound the doctor becomes aware that it will require extensive debridement before good healing will occur. The term debridement means to
options: irrigate the wound to remove blood clots
cauterize all bleeding points and wash out blood clots
tie off blood vessels and nerves deep in the wound
cut away all damage and necrotic tissue and remove and foreign material
questions.explanation: Debridement removes foreign material and necrotic tissue.

questions.question: due to the nature of James wound prophylactic IV antibiotics and intravenous therapy is to be commenced. The doctor prescribes a litre of dextrose/saline over 8 hours. The giving set you use has a drop factor of 60 drops/ml. Which of the following flow rates will ensure James receives the IV fluid within the correct time frame
questions.explanation: 8‑hourly dosing (q8h): 3 doses/day; drip calc depends—given DF60 sugar water? Typical 125 dpm for 500 mL/1 hr; best option 125 given choices.

questions.question: As James waits to be transferred to theatre you note his bleeding is increasing and you monitor him more closely. What changes to his vital signs would you expect to see if his blood loss becomes excessive
options: Slowing of pulse rate, increasing blood pressure, elevated temperature
Increasing pulse rate, stable blood pressure, elevated temperature
Stable pulse rate, dropping blood pressure, normal temperature
Increasing pulse rate, dropping blood pressure, normal temperature
questions.explanation: Hypovolaemia: tachycardia with falling BP; temp often normal initially.

questions.question: James is becoming shocked in this instance. What type of shock will this be
questions.explanation: Blood loss → hypovolaemic shock.

questions.question: Physiological compensation by the body in this type of shock will include all of the following except
options: Increased pumping efficiency of the heart
Fluid shift extra cellular to intravascular
Increased sodium excretion of sodium by the kidneys
questions.explanation: Kidneys conserve sodium/water; increased excretion is NOT compensatory.

questions.question: Henare is a 25 year old man admitted for emergency surgery, he has a left inguinal hernia which is nonreducible. This means that he has
options: A weakness in the abdominal wall opening through which the spermatic cord emerges
A hernia sac which does not return to the abdominal cavity as a result of swelling
Abdominal content, usually omentum or intestine descending into the groin or scrotum creating a mass
A direct inguinal hernia resulting from bowel and bladder content passing through the posterior inguinal wall Page 124 of 203
questions.explanation: Nonreducible hernia: sac does not return due to swelling/incarceration.

questions.question: Pat is a 20 year old woman with a diagnosis of PID (pelvic inflammatory disease). Her nursing assessment includes temperature 38.4c, moderate lower abdominal pain, and an offensive vaginal discharge. Nursing interventions for pats care would include
options: Bed and chair rest with legs elevated
Monitor temperature and pulse twice daily
Nurse at rest in a semi fowlers position
Monitor blood pressure three times a day
questions.explanation: Hernia most common in males due to inguinal canal anatomy.

questions.question: Pat asks you is it true that some STDs can cause cervical cancer. Your answer would be
options: Persistent infection with certain types of HPV (genital warts) is linked to cervical cancer risk
No; most STIs directly cause cervical cancer
Multiple partners increase risk only by raising exposure to HPV, not by themselves
Genital herpes (HSV) alone has not been proven to cause cervical cancer
questions.explanation: Cervical cancer is causally linked with high‑risk HPV infection. Herpes simplex (HSV) is not established as a cause; risk relates to HPV exposure and persistence.

questions.question: Nina is 33 years old, she has had rheumatoid arthritis for the last five years, and is currently suffering from an exacerbation of her disease. You are visiting Nina with the district nurse. Although Nina is troubled with pain, she is most worried about caring for her 8 month old son and her home. Nina and the nurse establish a plan to manage Nina's pain which is related to joint inflammation. Which of the following strategies will provide relief for her
options: Applying warm, moist compresses 30 minutes before doing house hold activities requiring hand and finger movements
Taking salicylates after activity to decrease the inflammation caused by activity
Loosing 5 kg to limit stress placed on joints
Applying cold compresses after activities to numb the pain if it does occur
questions.explanation: Strangulated hernia compromises blood supply—surgical emergency.

questions.question: Which is the correct statement about rheumatoid arthritis? This disease
options: Affects both men and women equally
Mainly affects the larger weight bearing joints
Is a systemic disease with multiple joint involvement
questions.explanation: Antibiotics reduce wound infection risk pre‑op.

questions.question: Mrs Mary brown, aged 34 years, has had abdominal surgery. 24 hours later she complains of pain in her left calf. Your first action should be to
options: Palpate the calf to note tenderness or pain
Ask Mrs. brown to extend her leg and dorsi flex her foot and note if this causes pain
Measure the circumference of the right and left calves and note the difference
questions.explanation: Cannabinoids/opiates cross placenta—fetal risk.

questions.question: Compartment syndrome is a possible complication of fractures. Which assessment data should the nurse report immediately
options: Increasing pain out of proportion to the sustained injury
Capillary refill which takes two seconds
Parathesia which decreases with movement of the affected part
Mild oedema of the affected limb Page 125 of 203
questions.explanation: Bronchodilators relieve bronchospasm.

questions.question: Mrs skinner has a blood transfusion in progress following hip replacement .her blood group is a. This means that in an emergency she could receive blood from
questions.explanation: Asthma attack priority: relieve bronchospasm and improve oxygenation.

questions.question: Twelve hours after the operation Mrs. skinner started shivering and complaining of pain in her back. Her pulse was very rapid. In these circumstances which one of the following should the nurse do first
questions.explanation: Teach pursed‑lip breathing to reduce air trapping.

questions.question: The most probable explanation for Mrs. skinners symptoms is
options: An allergic reaction to the blood transfusion
An allergic reaction to the metal prosthesis
questions.explanation: Nebulised β₂ agonists relax bronchial smooth muscle.

questions.question: John an 18 year old student, has been assigned to your care. He is jaundiced and his clinical appearance suggests that he has hepatitis a. Hepatitis a is an inflammatory condition of the liver caused by
options: Auto immune processes following a viral infection
a virus which infects the person via the GI system
a virus which is only transmitted via contaminated blood products
a virus which is mainly transmitted by sharing needles
questions.explanation: Theophylline relaxes bronchial smooth muscle (bronchodilation).

questions.question: following a bout of hepatitis A most people can expect
questions.explanation: Status asthmaticus is life‑threatening—urgent treatment.

questions.question: the jaundice in hepatitis a is best described a
questions.explanation: Avoid precipitants; inhaled steroids for control.

questions.question: the incubation period is
questions.explanation: Continue regular maintenance meds even if asymptomatic.

questions.question: Smoking is bad for people with chronic respiratory disorders because cigarette smoke
options: Destroys the cilia which cleanse debris from the airways
Inhibit s the inspiratory centres in the central nervous system
Inhibit nerves involved in the reflex pathways involved in coughing Page 126 of 203
Prevents the vocal cords closing tightly together when swallowing
questions.explanation: Mucolytics/expectorants are adjuvants; bronchodilators still help in chronic disease.

questions.question: One reason why smokers with chronic respiratory problems should not be given medications that inhibit the cough reflex, as
options: These medications dry up mucous and make secretions difficult to expel
The hypoxic drive is inhibited causing a slow in breathing rate
Coughing is their only means of preventing mucous accumulating in the lungs
In people with chronic problems these medications have no effect anyway
questions.explanation: Chest physio helps mobilise secretions in bronchiectasis.

questions.question: Asthma is a disorder primarily characterised by
options: Hyperinflation and over expansion of lung tissue
Spastic constriction of the respiratory airways
A breakdown in the walls of alveolar tissue
Chronic dilation and expansion of the airways
questions.explanation: Asthma primarily involves bronchospasm and airway inflammation.

questions.question: During acute asthmatic attacks theophylline medications are given because they
questions.explanation: Theophylline/aminophylline dilate bronchioles.

questions.question: Aminophylline comes in ampoules of 250mgs in 10mls. How much in mls, would you draw up to obtain 300mgs
questions.explanation: (300 mg ÷ 25 mg/mL) × 10 mL? Actually 250 mg in 10 mL → 25 mg/mL; 300/25=12 mL → 12.0.

questions.question: In the early stages of obstruction to urine flow, symptoms which a client with an enlarged prostate gland might experience include
options: Difficulty in emptying his bladder and Haematuria
Foul smelling urine with a high bacteria count
Complete retention of urine and dribbling
Frequency, urgency, a poor stream and nocturia
questions.explanation: BPH early: frequency, urgency, poor stream, nocturia.

questions.question: A client is prescribed 1 litre of dextrose/saline to be given over 3 hours. If the IV giving set has a drop factor of 15 drops per ml, which of the following, in drops per minute, gives the correct rate
questions.explanation: 1 L over 8 h, DF 40? If standard DF 20? Given options, 33 dpm is typical for 1L/8h with 40 gtt/mL; choose 33.

questions.question: Your client states that she is most unhappy with the care she is receiving from her doctor and wishes to change doctors. You respond
options: Would you like to talk to me about why you are unhappy with your care – I may be able to help
Okay should be no problem, it‟s your choice after all
I don‟t think that‟s a good idea – it can glad to the doctor becoming annoyed Page 127 of 203
Hospital policy does not allow for you to make a choice of doctor but would you like to talk to me about your concerns
questions.explanation: Toxic megacolon risk is serious—monitor closely.

questions.question: Jenny is 22 years old and has been admitted under section 8 of the mental health act (1992). This period of assessment of jenny is for
questions.explanation: Ulcerative colitis causes diarrhoea with blood and mucus.

questions.question: Jenny feels frightened and is obviously psychotic. She feels persecuted and has paranoid delusions that we will harm her. Delusions, like this are
options: False ideas that are entrenched and permanent
Fixed, false beliefs that do not respond to reasoning
Transitory fantasies which diminish with medication
Illogical ideas which can be reasoned and explained to her
questions.explanation: High‑fibre diet is contraindicated in acute flare—use low‑residue.

questions.question: Jenny‟s family tell you that they feel frightened when she talks about people who are going to harm her. They ask you what they should say. A therapeutic response to the family would be
options: Talk about something else and distract Jenny's attention
Identify that you know she is really going to be harmed
Identify with how she is feeling and state what you see as reality
Tell them to ignore the comments and respond positively to jenny
questions.explanation: Sulfasalazine can cause crystalluria—encourage fluids; or folate deficiency—supplement.

questions.question: Jenny has been commenced on chlorpromazine medication and has been sitting outdoors. She complains of sunburn and you note how reddened her skin seems. As a nurse you are aware that his is due to
options: Ultraviolet light and the fairness of Jenny‟s skin
A skin reaction to the medication jenny commenced
Increased photosensitivity to ultraviolet light from the chlorpromazine
Allergic reaction to the medication and subsequent redness of skin
questions.explanation: Monitor electrolytes due to diarrhoea/dehydration.

questions.question: Jenny approaches you, clasping your hands and telling you she needs help. You note that her eyes appear to have rolled backwards and that her neck is rigid. Your nursing diagnosis is
options: Attention seeking behaviour with manipulative overtones
Parkinson‟s disease and high level of anxiety
Oculogyric crisis due to extra pyramidal side effects
Akathisia due to side effects from the medication
questions.explanation: Lithium action onset delayed; antipsychotics act faster for acute mania.

questions.question: In an acute presentation, such as jenny, the need to administer medication so as to address the situation is important. The most likely choice of drug would be
questions.explanation: Lithium toxicity risk with dehydration—maintain fluid and salt intake.

questions.question: When administering this medication what is the dosage and upper limit or ceiling in a twenty four hour period Page 128 of 203
questions.explanation: Renal function must be adequate for lithium therapy.

questions.question: Following this episode, jenny is commenced on a regular anticholinergic antiparkinsonian drug. The most likely drug of choice would be
questions.explanation: Lethargy/weakness and GI upset suggest lithium toxicity.

questions.question: Jenny is charted this medication. Which of the following drug orders reflects the amount/dosage to be received accurately
questions.explanation: Fine tremor is common; coarse tremor signals toxicity.

questions.question: Jenny responds well to her care and is discharged 14 days later. She is charted an antipsychotic injectable medication which the mental health nurse gives her at home. The medication is flupenthixol deaconate. The dosage and frequency is likely to be
questions.explanation: Hypothyroidism can occur on lithium—monitor thyroid function.

questions.question: Tom has a diagnosis of bipolar affective disorder and his family ask you to talk with them about it. They ask you what an affective disorder is. A therapeutic response would be
options: An abnormality in the mood or feeling state of a person
A dysfunctional emotive illness exacerbated intermittently
A chronic and progressive deterioration in the emotion of a person
A strange feeling which is abnormal in origin
questions.explanation: Lithium toxicity features GI upset and neuro signs.

questions.question: Tom is due for a test today and the lab technicians arrive to do the blood test. Tom asks you what the level needed in his blood is. A correct response is
questions.explanation: Regular serum lithium level checks are essential.

questions.question: Toms level comes back from the lab who ring you to tell you that his level is very high. The immediate nursing actions would involve
options: A check to see if a.m. dose was given, discontinue meds and notify doctor
Commencement on fluid balance chart and vital recordings
Encourage fluid intake and continue meds and document observations
Inform tom he is toxic, place on bed rest and notify next of kin Page 129 of 203
questions.explanation: Sodium depletion increases lithium levels—maintain intake.

questions.question: Tom is assessed and has lithium toxicity. The symptoms we would expect to see as nurses are
options: Coarse tremor, diarrhoea, vomiting and sluggishness
Thirst, nausea, skin rash and pain on dorsal flexion
questions.explanation: Coarse tremor, vomiting, diarrhoea indicate toxicity.

questions.question: You are a domiciliary nurse and have been visiting Liz in the community. Liz is receiving an antipsychotic in infectable form. Which medication is not an injectable antipsychotic
questions.explanation: Thioridazine is not available as a depot; others are depot forms.

questions.question: Before Liz was commenced on her medication you asked that she be charted a test dose. This lower dose is
options: Given then reviewed after 5 days before regular charting begins
Given fortnightly for a period of six months
Administered and then followed immediately by a regular dose if no reaction is noted
Administered once and then repeated weekly for four weeks
questions.explanation: Test dose is given and reviewed after several days for reactions before regular dosing.

questions.question: Liz continues to request that her injection site be in her buttock and refuses to have it in the thigh. You have permission to do this. You assure the accurate site by
options: Locating the upper, outer quadrant of the buttock
Locating the lower, outer quadrant of the buttock
Locating the iliac crest and administering the injection
Locating the midline and injecting 3cms to the side of it
questions.explanation: Ventrogluteal: upper outer quadrant to avoid sciatic nerve.

questions.question: In regularly dispensing injectable medication you are aware as a nurse that the medication is locally irritating. You therefore
options: Administer it in one area only
Rub the area gently following administration
Rotate sites and do not rub/massage the area
Apply heat and massage the area
questions.explanation: Rotate injection sites; avoid rubbing irritating meds.

questions.question: Jan is a first line manager responsible for the care of a group of patients. She is concerned because for the last three weeks the physiotherapist has been late to see the patients and sometimes has not come at all. She has called the physiotherapist but the situation has not improved. Jan‟s next action should be to
options: Write a memo to the physiotherapy department
Notify the physician of the situation
questions.explanation: Notify responsible physician to address interprofessional issue.

questions.question: In organisations the primary management function is to
options: Establish a framework in which to function Page 130 of 203
questions.explanation: Collaborate and give consistent responses to limit-testing behaviour.

questions.question: Cohesiveness is important to all teams. This means
options: The process a group goes through in deciding what to do
A mutual attraction which holds a group together
A decision made by a knowledgeable leader for the group
A strong organisational support system of the group
questions.explanation: Set boundaries and offer choices within limits.

questions.question: Part of Jan's position requires her to manage the budget. This is
questions.explanation: Use clear, simple, brief directions.

questions.question: Jan is aware that nursing tasks and quality of nursing practice are compared with which pivotal question
options: Does the performance match standards and objectives
Does the performance reflect interest and enthusiasm for the job
Does performance indicate knowledge and expertise
Does performance leave the patients comfortable
questions.explanation: Positive reinforcement strengthens desired behaviour.

questions.question: Elanore brown aged 20, is a passenger who is thrown clear when the car she is travelling in hits a lamp post. Eleanor exhibits internal bleeding later diagnosed a ruptured spleen. First aid care for Eleanor includes elevating her limbs. This is done to
questions.explanation: Use calm, firm limit‑setting when hostile.

questions.question: Eleanor is admitted to the accident and emergency department in advanced stage two shock. When taking her base line observations you would expect to find
options: Elevated BP, elevated pulse rate and elevated respiratory rate
Decreased BP, decreased pulse rate and decreased respiratory rate
Decreased BP, increased pulse rate and increased respiratory rate
Decreased BP, decreased pulse rate and increased respiratory rate
questions.explanation: Use least restrictive methods; avoid seclusion unless necessary.

questions.question: Eleanor is catheterised and her urine output is monitored hourly. This is done to
options: Provide an indication of her renal perfusion
Ensure she does not go into fluid overload
Ensure she is receiving adequate hydration
Monitor the concentration of serum electrolytes
questions.explanation: Encourage reality‑based groups and social skills.

questions.question: Eleanor also requires additional nursing observations. Which of the following is the most appropriate
options: Mental status exam and urinary electrolytes
Level of consciousness and abdominal girth
Papillary reaction to light and limb movement Page 131 of 203
Swallowing reflex and orientation to time and place
questions.explanation: Experienced nurse models therapeutic communication.

questions.question: A sample of Eleanor‟s blood is sent to the laboratory for cross matching. When Eleanor‟s blood group has been identified the best treatment for her is to transfuse her with
questions.explanation: Sit quietly nearby—support without pressuring to talk.

questions.question: John smith aged 50 receives 30% burns to his face, neck, arms and upper thorax when he pours petrol onto his barbecue. The most appropriate immediate first aid treatment for Mr. smith is to
options: Roll him in a damp rug to extinguish the flames
Remove his burning clothes as fast as possible
Quickly throw him into the swimming pool
Quickly roll him in a wet sheet and apply ice to his burns
questions.explanation: Milieu therapy structures environment for safety and growth.

questions.question: Smoke inhalation can complicate burn injuries. While waiting the ambulance the most appropriate position for conscious victims of smoke inhalation is
options: Sitting in the semi fowlers position
Lying supine with the legs elevated
questions.explanation: Early psychosis signs include social withdrawal and odd behaviour.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct with regard to burn injuries
options: Partial thickness burns are not painful as the nerve endings are destroyed
Full thickness burns are often very painful as the nerve endings are irritated
Full thickness burns are often not painful as the nerve endings are destroyed
Blistering and redness often occur very quickly following a full thickness burn
questions.explanation: Encourage participation without confrontation.

questions.question: Factors determining the severity of the burn injury include
options: Depth of burn and percentage of body surface area burnt
Location of the burn on the body and age of the victim
Size of the burn and previous medical history of the victim
All of the above STATE EXAMS 14
questions.explanation: Depressant (alcohol) withdrawal peaks 24–48h with tremor, agitation.

questions.question: You consider Joe to be quite disturbed and communicate this to Joe‟s doctor. Eventually Joe is hospitalised for assessment and treatment. Joe continues to have delusions. Reality for Joe will be reinforced by 1. Listening to him carefully 2. Calling him by name 3. Calling him at mealtimes 4. Reminding him to change his clothes
questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines are used for alcohol withdrawal symptom control.

questions.question: In view of his age and stage of development, and given his disorder thinking, Joe will most likely need all except
questions.explanation: Hallucinations/delusions require antipsychotics as ordered.

questions.question: Therapeutically, doing what you say you will is important in establishing
questions.explanation: Keeping your word fosters trust.

questions.question: At the next team meeting it is decided to commence Joe on medication in an attempt to impose a control on his disorder thoughts. Of the following, which will contribute most to the teams choice of the mode of administration of the drug
options: The amount of insight about his situation
Joes trust in the medical staff
Joes trust in his primary nurse
questions.explanation: Route choice depends on adherence; depot if non‑compliant with orals.

questions.question: Of the following which is likely to contribute to the choice selecting a depot medication for a patient
options: The patient requesting the medication be given by injection
Convenience for the community psychiatric nurse
Likelihood of the client defaulting with oral medications
questions.explanation: Depot best if likelihood of nonadherence to oral meds is high.

questions.question: In any situation where restraint is necessary, which of the following is not true
options: Questions asked by the patient are answered by one staff member
One staff member per limb is the minimum safe requirement
Medication will always be given to effect control
The patient is most safely restrained lying down
questions.explanation: Medication is not always required when restraining; least restrictive first.

questions.question: When caring for potentially suicidal patients, the nurse should 1. Respect their right to privacy foremost 2. Know their where3abouts at all times 3. Remove dangerous objects from their rooms 4. Allow weekend leave to boost morale
questions.explanation: Remove dangerous objects and increase observation (1 and 2).

questions.question: Mr white is a depressed patient who has said „I‟m fed up. I don‟t intend to go on like this‟ the nurse should
options: Ask him directly if he is considering suicide
Ignore the statement and continue the conversation Page 133 of 203
Change the subject but report incident to charge nurses
Comment that others are worse off than he is
questions.explanation: Tricyclics side effects: tachycardia, anticholinergic, orthostatic hypotension.

questions.question: Disulfiram (antabuse) is given to people suffering from alcoholism
questions.explanation: Neuroleptics mainly reduce dopamine activity.

questions.question: Which of the following is a temporary form of amnesia, usually occurring at higher levels of intoxication
questions.explanation: Lithium narrow index—monitor levels and educate about toxicity.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a progressive stage of addiction
questions.explanation: St John's Wort interacts; but likely: combine pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy as ordered.

questions.question: When a person tries to make up for weaknesses in one area by playing up strengths in another, it is termed
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A incubation ~15–50 days; B 45–160; C 15–150.

questions.question: The client you are caring for under section 8 of the mental health act (1992) declines their medication. At what stage does verbal consent need to be given before assessment and treatment can continue
options: one month in to the compulsory treatment order
At any time during the hospitalisation
Following the second extension of the compulsory treatment order
Whenever consent is sought for treatments
questions.explanation: Hepatitis B incubates about 60–90 days (range 45–180).

questions.question: The act specifically excludes a number of diagnostic groups from compulsory assessment and treatment. These include
options: Substance abuse, intellectual handicap and personality disorder
Hebephrenia, schizo affective illness and drug induced psychoses
Paranoid schizophrenia, bi polar affective disorder and psychoses
questions.explanation: Hep A—faecal–oral transmission.

questions.question: A family approach you for information about compulsory treatment orders and the length of time that these are for. An appropriate response would be
options: A period of six months initially and then an extension of the order may be sought
For an indefinite period which is always variable
You need to ask the judge who will determine this
For a one year period and then reviewed annually Page 134 of 203
questions.explanation: Hep B—blood/body fluids, sexual, perinatal.

questions.question: Mr Elias who is a 19 year old, pakeha male, who has been admitted to ED following a motorbike accident. Mr Elias had been drinking heavily in isolation prior to the accident and his flatmates had discovered a suicide note in his room. In the admitting room doctors have made a provisional diagnosis of head injury, right pneumothorax and a compound fracture of his right tibia and fibula. Emergency nursing in this situation is concerned with focussing on your patients immediate needs and setting priority of care. Therefore your first nursing action is to
options: Suction his airway and administer oxygen by mask
Do a rapid assessment for baseline blood pressure and pulse
Assess for clear airway and presence of respirations
Assess levels of consciousness and papillary reaction
questions.explanation: Hepatitis C—blood‑borne (needles).

questions.question: The Glasgow coma scale is used to establish the level of consciousness. All of the following are used except
questions.explanation: Jaundice occurs when bilirubin accumulates causing yellowing.

questions.question: Changes in the patient‟s condition which would indicate increasing intracranial pressure are
options: Stable level of consciousness, increasing pulse rate, widening pulse pressure
Stable level of consciousness, increasing pulse rate, stable pulse pressure
Increasing level of consciousness, decreasing pulse rate, narrow pulse pressure
Decreasing level of consciousness, decreasing pulse rate, widening pulse pressure
questions.explanation: Pruritus due to bile salt deposition in skin.

questions.question: Mr Elias general condition deteriorates with hypovolemic shock. The cardinal signs of which are
options: Slowing of pulse rate, increasing blood pressure, elevated temperature
Increasing pulse rate, stable blood pressure, elevated temperature
Increasing pulse rate, dropping blood pressure, normal temperature
Stable pulse rate, dropping blood pressure, normal temperature
questions.explanation: Dark urine from conjugated bilirubin excretion.

questions.question: To evaluate the effectiveness of fluid replacement for the patient in hypovolemic shock, you would first look for return to normal range of
questions.explanation: Clay stools from lack of bile pigments in intestine.

questions.question: Mr Elias compound fracture of the tibia and fibula is immobilised by open reduction and internal fixation. A nurse, new to the orthopaedic area asks you to explain what is meant by open reduction and internal fixation. You reply
options: Bring both bone ends into alignment by surgical intervention and holding them in position with a metal plate and screws
Bringing bone ends into alignment by external manipulation and holding them in position with a Steinmann pin and traction
Bringing bone ends into alignment by external manipulation and holding them in position by an external fixing device Page 135 of 203
Bringing both bone ends into alignment by surgical intervention and holding them in position by a tight back slab and firm bandage
questions.explanation: Icterus indicates high bilirubin (hyperbilirubinaemia).

questions.question: Mr Evans is a twenty year old patient admitted with hepatitis B to a medical ward you are working on. Jaundice has developed because
options: The liver is unable to absorb vitamin B
Of the damaged livers inability to metabolise bilirubin
Liver enzymes are released and liver function decreases
questions.explanation: Jaundice due to impaired bilirubin metabolism in damaged liver.

questions.question: For which of the following reasons would a patient with jaundice develop the nursing diagnosis of high risk for impaired skin integrity
options: Jaundice is associated with decubitus formation
Jaundice produces pruritus due to impaired bile excretion
Jaundice leads to decreased tissue perfusion
questions.explanation: Pruritus increases scratching and skin breakdown risk.

questions.question: Henare is a 25 year old man admitted for emergency surgery, he has a left inguinal hernia which is nonreducible. This means that he has
options: A weakness in the abdominal wall opening through which the spermatic cord emerges
A hernia sac which does not return to the abdominal cavity a result of swelling
Abdominal content, usually omentum or intestine descending into the groin, or scrotum creating a mass
A direct inguinal hernia resulting from bowel and bladder content passing through the posterior inguinal wall
questions.explanation: Nonreducible hernia = sac cannot return due to swelling/incarceration.

questions.question: Pat asks you „is it true that some STDs can cause cervical cancer‟ your answer would be
options: Persistent infection with certain types of HPV (genital warts) is linked to cervical cancer risk
No; most STIs directly cause cervical cancer
Multiple partners increase risk only by raising exposure to HPV, not by themselves
Genital herpes (HSV) alone has not been proven to cause cervical cancer
questions.explanation: Cervical cancer is causally linked with high‑risk HPV infection. Herpes simplex (HSV) is not established as a cause; risk relates to HPV exposure and persistence.

questions.question: Four purposes of chromosomal studies, amniocentesis is most commonly performed
options: Usually not until after the 12th week
Usually not until after the 20th week
questions.explanation: Amniocentesis usually after 12 weeks (often 15–18 weeks).

questions.question: Tina, a midwife, tells an antenatal class that progesterone is considered the hormone most responsible for maintaining pregnancy. Where is the primary source of progesterone found throughout most of the pregnancy
questions.explanation: Placenta is main progesterone source after ~10–12 weeks.

questions.question: Larry and Mary smith had planned their first pregnancy for some time, but when it is confirmed, Mary feels conflicting emotions. She comes to the clinic for her first prenatal (antenatal) visit at ten weeks gestation. Mary shares her mixed feelings about the pregnancy with the midwife. The midwifes best response would be to
options: Encourage her to consider abortion counselling
Encourage her to seek support from Larry
Reassure her that when she feels the baby move, her mixed feelings will disappear completely
Reassure her that most women experience some mixed feelings in early pregnancy, even when their pregnancies are planned
questions.explanation: Progesterone maintains uterine quiescence by relaxing smooth muscle.

questions.question: During a subsequent visit, Mary states she has begun to feel foetal movement. Foetal movement is usually felt by the pregnancy woman when the foetus is approximately
questions.explanation: Quickening felt ~16–20 weeks; nulliparas later.

questions.question: Mary and Larry are proud parents of a baby girl weighing 3050 gms. The apgar is nine at one minute. With an above apgar score the baby‟s
options: Body is pink but extremities are blue
questions.explanation: Prior low birth weight increases risk for LBW infant.

questions.question: You assess Mary‟s fundus and find the fundus to be firm and off centre. You would suspect
options: The fundus is not well contracted
There are clots in the fundus
questions.explanation: Third trimester weight gain ~0.5 kg/week (about 1 lb).

questions.question: On day five Mary, and her baby are ready for discharge. You tell Mary that should her vaginal bleeding increase excessively (secondary postpartum haemorrhage), she should notify her primary care given immediately. The most likely cause will be
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency anaemia defined by low Hb; give iron and vitamin C.

questions.question: Mary is breast feeding for the first time. She may require assistance. What is the most important factor to ensure successful breast feeding
options: Ensure baby is attached to breast properly
Ensure baby‟s suction is broken before detaching from breast
A support person is with her while feeding
questions.explanation: Folate prevents neural tube defects; increase green leafy veg intake.

questions.question: Another mother tui also chooses to breastfeed. You are aware that breastfeeding is a natural form of contraception in that it is 98 effective, providing that Page 137 of 203
options: The baby is less than six months old and taking most of the nourishment from breast milk
The mothers menses have not returned and the baby is less than six months old
The baby is less than nine months old and feeding six to eight times per day
The baby is less than nine months old and has been fully breastfeed
questions.explanation: Folic acid supplement advised from preconception through first trimester.

questions.question: During the discussion tui and henare ask what the Guthrie test is for you reply it is a test that
options: Assesses haemoglobin levels in the new born
Assesses the babies serum bilirubin levels
questions.explanation: Iron best absorbed on empty stomach with vitamin C; stools may darken.

questions.question: You are the staff nurse working in the children‟s ward. You are caring for Hugh Jones aged 4, who has been admitted with meningitis. Hugh‟s parents are upset and feeling guilty that they did not recognise highs illness earlier. Your response would be to
options: Inform them about meningitis and discuss how they could have recognised it earlier
Tell them they should have taken Hugh to the doctor earlier and consequently he would not have been as sick as he is now
Reassure them the effects of meningitis occur over a period of time and that they could not have acted any sooner
Get the doctor to come and speak to them about the effects the disease will have on Hugh
questions.explanation: Calcium supports maternal and fetal bone mineralisation.

questions.question: Meningitis is a life threatening illness and it poses a grave concern for hughs parents. As Hughes nurse you help to reduce their anxiety by the following 1. Educate them about the illness so they can understand its effects on Hugh 2. Explain procedures so they can understand and help with highs care 3. Explain that Hughes irritability is part of the illness 4. Give them time to discuss their concerns
questions.explanation: Exclusive breastfeeding recommended for first 6 months.

questions.question: Benjamin Johnson, aged 4 falls off his bike when playing. You are working in the emergency department when he is admitted. Using the Glasgow coma scale you assess all of the following except
options: His ability to open his eyes
questions.explanation: Immunisations protect through active immunity development.

questions.question: You also observe Benjamin for signs of increased intracranial pressure which include
options: Increase in pulse rate, drop in blood pressure
Increase in pulse rate, rise in blood pressure
Decrease in pulse rate, rise in blood pressure
Decrease in pulse rate, drop in blood pressure Page 138 of 203
questions.explanation: Allergy history guides safe immunisation practice.

questions.question: You are working with the public health nurse in a large urban area. You visit a day care centre at the request of the staff to visit Joel Hinton, aged 3 years. The staff are concerned because Joel is becoming disruptive, has poor concentration, and has visible bruising. He has walked with a limp for the past week. On arrival at the day care centre, you would
options: Observe Joel at play with other children
Ring Joel's family to ask them what is wrong with Joel
talk to the staff about Joel
assess the situation and meet with Joel
questions.explanation: Egg allergy relevant to some vaccines (e.g., older influenza preps).

questions.question: you are going to report your suspicions regarding Joel to the appropriate authority. The appropriate authority in this situation is
options: Joel‟s teacher at school or principal
Joel‟s general practitioner or practice nurse
the police, or department of social welfare
questions.explanation: Fever post‑immunisation may be normal; monitor and symptomatic care.

questions.question: Sarah miles has brought her six week old daughter Sophie in to see the public health nurse you are working with .she wants to talk about the immunisation schedule as she is not sure if she should have Sophie immunised. She expresses concern that Sophie may react to the vaccine. The public health nurses best response would be
options: yes, this can happen but the research is inconclusive
this is very rare, however you and Sophie should stay for 20 minutes after the vaccine
don‟t worry as the chance of Sophie having a reaction is minimal
don‟t worry as this is only of concern if another member of your family has reacted to a vaccination
questions.explanation: Family history of reaction does not contraindicate infant immunisation; assess individual risk.

questions.question: Sarah asks how immunisations work. You explain the differences between active and passive immunisation. Which of the following is not associated with passive immunisation
options: human globulin is given containing antibodies
this type of immunity is provided through breastfeeding
questions.explanation: Passive immunity is temporary, not lifelong.

questions.question: the following day, Louisa whiti attends the clinic with her son Jayden, aged 3 years. Louisa has noted Jayden‟s behaviour is more disruptive than usual, and he does not respond to her calling him. Your initial nursing assessment would include which of the following
options: telling Louisa about the possibility of sibling rivalry
reassuring Louisa this is normal behaviour for a 3 year old
inspection of both ears and a hearing test
questions.explanation: Assess hearing and inspect ears first when speech concerns arise.

questions.question: later that afternoon, Susan Jones aged 4 years comes to the clinic with her father anu. Susan has had recurrent bilateral otitis media with effusion for 6 months. She is booked for a myringotomy next week. Anu asks what this means. A myringotomy is
options: a surgical incision of the mastoid
a surgical incision of the tympanic membrane Page 139 of 203
a surgical incision of the Eustachian tube
the surgical removal of the adenoids
questions.explanation: Myringotomy = incision in tympanic membrane.

questions.question: john is unit manager in a local hospital. John is trying to build a climate of accountability in this unit. This means
options: nurses should involve patients and families in decisions and offer explanations for actions
registered nurses should report back to the unit manager regularly through the day
the unit manager is ultimately responsible for all the registered nurses actions
all of the above are true of accountability
questions.explanation: Accountability includes involving patients, explaining actions.

questions.question: john realises however that as a nurse manager he is accountable for his decisions. He takes this to mean that
options: he is able to make decisions in accordance with his beliefs and values
what is best for the patient overrides all other considerations
he is responsible for his actions and the consequence of his decisions
as nurse manager he is able to pass on to others praise or blame for outcomes of decisions
questions.explanation: Accountability = responsibility for actions and outcomes.

questions.question: accountability in the maintenance of quality nursing practice influenced most by
options: individual ideas regarding ethics, competence, commitment integrity
knowledge of professional standards and institutional and professional philosophy
knowledge of the nurses act and nursing councils role as well as malpractice decisions
all of the above have an influence
questions.explanation: Autonomy and accountability are fundamental professional values.

questions.question: john is unit manager at a large aged care centre unit. Because increased competition in all areas of health care john is keen to see quality maintained on the unit. Appropriate quality indicators he could used could be
options: repetition of work and adverse events
all of the above would be useful indicators
questions.explanation: Primary characteristics: core traits; secondary: less conspicuous.

questions.question: john wants the staff to understand quality assurance and the difference from quality control. He tells them that quality assurance means
options: staff must monitor their own practice and take responsibility
at the end of each week staff will reflect on ways to improve
that specific check points will be put in place to monitor progress
random audits will be done of nursing care to spot check
questions.explanation: Whole person includes physical and mental—holistic care.

questions.question: one way of improving quality is to set standards. These
options: are broad aims or goals of the organisation
form the basis of an organisation‟s mission statement
must be a specific statement about every aspect of care
describe what constitutes good care and state criteria to measure performance
questions.explanation: Discuss concerns and problem‑solve collaboratively.

questions.question: john found his staff were concerned to improve care and conserve resources. They agreed that standards
options: increased morale and empowered staff Page 140 of 203
facilitated staff thinking through and implementing change
enabled staff to put their own ideas into action
all of the above are true of this process
questions.explanation: Honesty underpins therapeutic relationship.

questions.question: current literature identifies serious difficulties faced by the novice entering the workforce. New graduates often experience reality shock. This could be described as
options: having to suddenly drop one set of values and adapt to a new subculture
a situation where one feels unhappy in the new job and decide to move on
surprise and disequilibrium experienced on moving from a familiar to a new culture
the challenge of becoming competent and effective in the new culture
questions.explanation: Respect autonomy and avoid coercion—provide information and support.

questions.question: the first phase of reality shock is often known as the honeymoon phase, graduates would be wise to
options: explain their values and beliefs at the onset so that co-workers understand them
be as helpful as possible to co workers and build up a support system
do their own work to the best of their ability and keep to themselves
share their new enthusiasm and try to motivate other staff to new ways
questions.explanation: Smoking is leading preventable risk for respiratory disease.

questions.question: gradually graduates move into the „recovery‟ phase; this is a time to
options: re evaluate values, keep worthwhile values and transfer them to work setting
drop all the professional values learnt in school and adapt to unit values
subjugate both school values and work values and decide not to cause problems
start to watch all advertisements and look for a better job
questions.explanation: Nurse’s role includes education and advocacy.

questions.question: Mrs. skinner has a blood transfusion in progress following hip replacement. Her blood group is a. This means that in an emergency she could receive blood from
questions.explanation: Hyperventilation lowers PaCO₂ (respiratory alkalosis).

questions.question: twelve hours after the operation Mrs. skinner started shivering and complaining of pain in her back. Her pulse was very rapid. In these circumstances which one of the following should the nurse do first
questions.explanation: Hypoventilation raises PaCO₂ (respiratory acidosis).

questions.question: the most probable explanation for Mrs. skinners symptoms is
options: an allergic reaction to the blood transfusion
an allergic reaction to the metal prosthesis
questions.explanation: Fever, malaise, and cough suggest infection; chest exam indicated.

questions.question: john an 18 year old student, has been assigned to your care. He is jaundiced and his clinical appearance suggests that he has hepatitis A. Hepatitis A is an inflammatory condition of the liver caused by
options: auto immune processes following a viral infection Page 141 of 203
a virus which infects the person via the GI system
a virus which is only transmitted via contaminated blood products
a virus which is mainly transmitted by sharing needles
questions.explanation: Vital signs monitor physiologic status changes.

questions.question: following a bout of hepatitis a most people can expect
questions.explanation: Humidification prevents mucous plugging in tracheostomy care.

questions.question: the jaundice in hepatitis A is best described as
questions.explanation: Semi‑Fowler’s improves ventilation in dyspnoea.

questions.question: the incubation period is
questions.explanation: Incubation of Hep A ~15–50 days.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a typical sign of early hepatitis
questions.explanation: Ascites is a later sign, not early.

questions.question: During the infectious stage, a person with hepatitis A is excreting the virus mainly in
questions.explanation: HAV excreted mainly in faeces during infectious stage.

questions.question: When a person is in the infectious stage of hepatitis A, special precautions are taken when you
options: Take a food tray to the person
questions.explanation: Special care when handling faeces/bedpans.

questions.question: A client has been back from surgery for several hours and has not asked for pain medication. The client and nurse are from different cultural groups. Being aware of cultural influences on health behaviours, the nurse will
options: Realize the client probably does not feel as much pain as some people
Wait for the client to ask before bringing pain medication
Look for non verbal signs of pain, such as holding the incision or lying still
Tell the client to be sure to call her if he/she is in pain Page 142 of 203
questions.explanation: Assess nonverbal cues; some cultures underreport pain verbally.

questions.question: Although the home health nurse has taught the client the importance of taking his antibiotic exactly every six hours, he still cannot seem to take it on schedule. In evaluating the effects of her teaching, the holistic nurse should consider that the client (who is from a different culture) possibly
options: Is relating to time differently than she
Has not understood what she taught
Does not believe the medicine will help
questions.explanation: Different cultural time orientation may affect scheduling.

questions.question: Smoking is bad for people with chronic respiratory disorders because cigarette smoke
options: Destroys the cilia which cleanse debris from the airways
Inhibits the inspiratory centres in the central nervous system
Inhibit nerves involved in the reflex pathways involved in coughing
Prevents the vocal cords closing tightly together when swallowing
questions.explanation: Respect cultural beliefs and accommodate within safety limits.

questions.question: One reason why smokers with chronic respiratory problems should not be given medications that inhibit the cough reflex is
options: These medication dry up mucous and make secretions difficult to expel
The hypoxic drive is inhibited causing a slowing in breathing rate
Coughing is their only means of preventing mucous accumulating in the lungs
In people with chronic problems these medications have no effect anyway
questions.explanation: Use professional interpreters rather than family when needed.

questions.question: Asthma is a disorder primarily characterised by
options: Hyperinflation and over expansion of lung tissue
Spastic constriction of the respiratory airways
A breakdown in the walls of alveolar tissue
Chronic dilation and expansion of the airways
questions.explanation: Some cultures view illness as imbalance—address beliefs respectfully.

questions.question: During acute asthmatic attacks theophylline medications are given because they
questions.explanation: Maintain privacy and modesty per cultural norms.

questions.question: Aminophylline comes in ampoules of 250mgs in 10mls. How much in mls, would you draw up to obtain 300mgs
questions.explanation: Use eye contact per cultural expectations carefully.

questions.question: In the early stages of obstruction to urine flow, symptoms which a client with an enlarged prostate gland might experience include
options: Difficulty in emptying his bladder and Haematuria
Foul smelling urine with a high bacteria count
Complete retention of urine and dribbling
Frequency, urgency, a poor stream and nocturia Page 143 of 203
questions.explanation: In some cultures, decision‑making may involve family/elders.

questions.question: A client is prescribed 1 litre of dextrose/saline to be given over 3 hours. If the IV giving set has a drop factor of 15 drops per ml, which of the following in drops per minute, gives the correct rate
questions.explanation: Exact incubation for Hep E varies; similar to Hep A ~15–60 days—select 30–40? Best option '3–8 weeks' if present; choose 20–40 days.

questions.question: Your client states that she is most unhappy with the care she is receiving from her doctor and wishes to change doctors. You respond
options: Would you like to talk to me about why you are unhappy with your care I may be able to help
